Executive Summary

Nootropic is a free-first, open-source-first AI/LLM-driven development environment and platform. Its chief aims are to provide developers with:
	1.	Advanced, dynamic project planning and management, through autonomous agents that decompose high-level intent into tasks, track state, and adjust plans in real time.
	2.	Deep code assistance and generation, leveraging local or cloud LLMs seamlessly (ModelAdapter) and integrating static analysis for continuous feedback (CriticAgent).
	3.	Rich RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) capabilities, using vector stores like Chroma/LanceDB/Milvus/Weaviate so agents can query large code/document corpora without context window limits.
	4.	Self-healing and self-teaching loops, where telemetry from LLM calls, CI/CD pipelines, and user feedback feed nightly fine-tuning (LoRA) and automated remediation (Keptn + LitmusChaos).
	5.	A unified user experience across CLI, VS Code extension, and Electron UI, where slash commands or wizard flows guide users through scaffolding, coding, searching, debugging, and deployment—all orchestrated under Nx’s monorepo.

Through modular micro-services (stateless containers and gRPC contracts), strong data-sovereign defaults (all code, embeddings, telemetry stay local unless explicitly opted into cloud), and a registry-driven plugin system, nootropic aspires to be the leanest yet most intelligent environment for AI-augmented software development.

⸻

1. Vision & Core Principles
	1.	Free-First, Opt-In Cloud
	•	Local-First Inference: Default to locally quantized models (Ollama, llama.cpp, Tabby ML, vLLM, Exllama) for cost-free, privacy-preserving usage.
	•	Cloud Fallback: Users may opt into premium cloud LLMs (OpenAI, Anthropic, Google) via simple configuration—without sacrificing a baseline fully-offline experience.
	2.	Modular, Extensible Micro-Services
	•	Each capability (planning, coding, search, storage, observability) is packaged as a stateless container or Nx library target, communicating over gRPC + Protobuf and streaming event buses (ReflexionAdapter).
	•	Agents register themselves in a Capability Registry so that CLI/VS Code/Electron can discover and invoke them dynamically.
	3.	Data-Sovereign by Default
	•	All code, embeddings, telemetry, and agent traces are stored locally (ChromaDB, LanceDB, SQLite/LevelDB, Prometheus/Grafana on-prem).
	•	No external data egress unless the user configures ModelAdapter to route to cloud or shares telemetry.
	4.	Self-Awareness & Self-Healing
	•	Agents (PlannerAgent, CoderAgent, CriticAgent, etc.) emit structured traces/logs that feed into telemetry (OpenTelemetry → Jaeger → Grafana).
	•	Keptn watches SLOs and Prometheus metrics; if a critical failure (CI test breach, high latency) is detected, it can roll back or trigger a LitmusChaos experiment.
	•	Continuous feedback (user “accept/reject” on code suggestions, static analysis fixes) is logged for nightly LoRA fine-tuning of local models (e.g., StarCoder 2), gradually improving suggestion accuracy without cloud spend.
	5.	Declarative Goals & Autonomous Execution
	•	Developers state high-level intent in a project-spec.yaml. The ProjectMgrAgent translates that into PDDL, generates a task graph (via Fast-Downward), and schedules tasks.
	•	Agents coordinate via a blackboard (vector + graph DB). Through a Reflexion Loop (RSM events), they converge on working pull requests with minimal manual intervention.
	6.	Unified UX in IDE + CLI + Desktop
	•	VS Code Extension (built on Continue + Roo Code) exposes slash commands—e.g., /plan, /code, /search—so coding, planning, testing, and deployment happen in one pane.
	•	CLI (Commander.js + Nx) offers registry-driven commands (nootropic wizard, nootropic plan, nootropic code, nootropic search, nootropic fix-tests, nootropic deploy, nootropic monitor, nootropic plugin:*).
	•	Electron Dashboard (React + Vite + Tailwind) provides Kanban boards, trace viewers, Mermaid/UML diagrams, and real-time metrics/alerts.

⸻

2. Architectural Layers & Components

Below is a concise breakdown of each major layer, its responsibilities, and key libraries or services:

2.1 User Interface Layer
	•	VS Code Extension
	•	Framework: Continue + Roo Code + LSP (via vscode-languageclient/server)
	•	Features: Inline chat, AST-safe diffs, multi-file refactoring, real-time collaboration
	•	Dependencies: @nootropic/runtime, @nootropic/context, @nootropic/ui
	•	CLI Client
	•	Framework: Commander.js + Nx executors
	•	Features: Registry-driven commands, JSON/YAML output, interactive wizards, progress bars
	•	Dependencies: @nootropic/runtime, @nootropic/cli, @nootropic/config
	•	Electron Dashboard
	•	Framework: Electron + React (via Electron-React boilerplate) + Vite
	•	Features: Kanban board for task graph, CoT logs for ExplainabilityAgent, real-time metrics (Grafana iframe), plugin manager UI
	•	Dependencies: @nootropic/ui, @nootropic/analytics, @nootropic/dashboard

2.2 Capability Registry
	•	Format & Location
	•	JSON at .nootropic-cache/describe-registry.json
	•	Schema enforced via Zod (capability name, version, description, dependencies, configSchema, exported commands)
	•	Responsibilities
	1.	Plugin Discovery: On startup, PluginLoaderAdapter scans plugins/, validates manifests via Zod, and writes entries to the registry.
	2.	Command Registration: CLI, VS Code, Electron pull from registry to show available slash commands / subcommands.
	3.	Dependency Resolution: Ensures that if a plugin requires a particular agent or adapter, that dependency is installed or loaded.
	4.	Version Compatibility: Registry checks that plugin’s compatibility (e.g., requires >=1.0.0 of ModelAdapter).

2.3 Orchestration Layer
	•	Temporal.io (v1.23+, persisted to local SQLite under .nootropic-cache/temporal)
	•	Hosts durable workflows: nightly LoRA fine-tuning, large batch refactors, CI remediation flows.
	•	Activities: capture LLM inference results, static analysis runs, backup jobs, and migration pipelines.
	•	Configuration lives under apps/temporal (Nx app), with workspace.json executor referencing Docker Compose or K8s deployment.
	•	RxJS (v8.0+)
	•	Provides reactive streams for per-agent event buses (ReflexionAdapter emits events like ModelSwitched, PlanUpdated, CodeFixApplied).
	•	Each agent subscribes to its relevant streams, performing backpressure handling (buffer, drop) and error strategies (retry, skip, fail).

2.4 Agents & Core Logic

Each “Agent” is essentially an Nx library (under libs/agents/) that runs as a separate process or container, exposing gRPC endpoints and participating in the Reflexion event bus.
	1.	PlannerAgent
	•	Purpose: Reads project-spec.yaml, generates a PDDL domain/problem triple, invokes Fast-Downward to compute a task graph DAG.
	•	Outputs: TaskGraph.json with dependencies, costs, resource constraints.
	•	Persistence: Snapshots state in LevelDB (agent:${agentId}:snapshot:${timestamp}) and emits a PlanUpdated event.
	2.	CoderAgent
	•	Purpose: Takes an individual task (e.g., “create user model and CRUD API”), crafts CoT prompts, calls ModelAdapter to generate or refactor code.
	•	Inputs: Task requirements, context from MemoryAgent or SearchAgent.
	•	Outputs: Diff patches (via Unified-Diff Parser) which are then applied (with preview) to the git working tree (SimpleGit handles commits).
	•	Feedback Loop: After patches are applied, it triggers CriticAgent.
	3.	CriticAgent
	•	Purpose: Performs static analysis (Semgrep with AI Autofix or OpenRewrite) and runs language-specific test suites (Jest for TS/JS, pytest for Python, JUnit for Java).
	•	Outputs: Lint/​security violations, code quality reports, suggested fixes. If tests fail, it triggers an event that the CoderAgent picks up to retry/​refine.
	4.	ReasoningAgent
	•	Purpose: Handles more abstract problem-solving tasks (e.g., “optimize SQL queries in this repository” or “migrate auth flow to OAuth2”).
	•	Mechanism: Calls local or cloud LLMs (via ModelAdapter), uses external knowledge (SearchAgent’s context retrieval), and proposes high-level plans or PRs.
	5.	SearchAgent
	•	Purpose: Manages embeddings → k-NN lookups.
	•	Vector Stores:
• ChromaDB (primary) for in-process, local embeddings (HNSW + FAISS).
• LanceDB fallback when Chroma surpasses a threshold (all-on-disk).
• Milvus (clustered) or Weaviate (hybrid vector + keyword) for large multi-repo setups.
	•	Pipeline: Watches repo files (Chokidar) → chunking (overlapping windows) → embed (via ModelAdapter) → upsert. Queries then return top-k passages for RAG context.
	6.	FeedbackAgent
	•	Purpose: Collects user feedback (“accepted/refused suggestion”, “rate this code 1–5”) and stores episodes in MemoryAgent.
	•	Fine-Tuning Loop: At night, triggers a Temporal workflow that reads accepted diffs, constructs LoRA training data, and kicks off a Tabby ML or vLLM LoRA job.
	7.	ProjectMgrAgent
	•	Purpose: Coordinates project-wide tasks (e.g., track which tasks are in progress vs. done, produce burndown charts, manage sprints).
	•	Dependencies: SLO monitor (Prometheus), Event store. Pushes updates to Electron UI (Kanban) and VS Code (progress markers).
	8.	ExplainabilityAgent
	•	Purpose: Surfaces chain-of-thought (CoT) logs and reasoning traces in the UI.
	•	Integration: Hooks into LLM calls (ModelAdapter) to capture prompt templates and token-level logs. Stores traces in LevelDB or SQLite so users can inspect why a suggestion was made.
	9.	MemoryAgent
	•	Purpose: Acts as an episodic store—logging (prompt, response, feedback, timestamp) tuples as embeddings in Chroma/LanceDB.
	•	Use Cases: When the CoderAgent needs examples, it can retrieve few-shot context from MemoryAgent. Also powers long-term “learning” by surfacing past good fixes.
	10.	ObservabilityAgent
	•	Purpose: Wraps OpenTelemetry instrumentation for all gRPC calls, LLM invocations, vector lookups, and storage ops.
	•	Outputs: Exposes /metrics endpoint (Prometheus), and exports OTLP spans to Jaeger. Enables Grafana dashboards for:
• LLM inference latency (nootropic_inference_latency_ms)
• Vector store throughput (nootropic_vector_ops_total)
• Event queue depth (nootropic_event_queue_depth)

2.5 Utility Adapters
	1.	ModelAdapter
	•	Purpose: Acts as a unified interface to multiple LLM backends.
	•	Local Runtimes:
• Ollama via local REST (http://localhost:11434/api/chat for chat, /api/generate for completion)
• llama.cpp for CPU/GPU inference (GGUF/​GGML), quantized to Q4/​Q5
• Tabby ML as a self-hosted completion server (uses vLLM under the hood)
• LM Studio for seamless local model management (GGUF + hardware acceleration)
	•	Cloud Runtimes (Opt-In):
• OpenAI (GPT-4o, GPT-4 Turbo) via openai SDK (key from ~/.nootropic/config.json)
• Anthropic (Claude Opus/4) via anthropic SDK
• HuggingFace Inference endpoints (via HuggingFace Hub SDK)
• Petals for peer-to-peer large model inference
	•	Model Registry:
• A JSON or SQLite-backed registry (model-metadata.json) that tracks: name, version, format (GGUF/GGML/LoRA), quantization, supported hardware (CUDA, Metal, Apple), cost (cloud vs. local).
• ModelAdapter uses registry + hardware detector (GPU count, VRAM, OS) to pick the optimal model: e.g., if 8 GB VRAM, pick starcoder2-q4_0, else fallback to CPU Llama 2 Q4.
	2.	StorageAdapter
	•	Purpose: Provides a uniform API to vector stores (Chroma, LanceDB, Milvus, Weaviate), relational stores (SQLite, PostgreSQL), and object stores (MinIO, S3).
	•	Responsibilities:
• Vector Operations: upsertEmbedding(), queryEmbeddings(), deleteEmbeddings()
• Document Operations: storeDocument(), searchDocument(), deleteDocument() (via Elasticsearch or full-text search in SQLite with FTS5)
• Cache Management: In-memory (Node-Cache) and Redis for ephemeral data (session tokens, rate limits)
• Backup/Restore: Snapshotting Chroma → MinIO, dumping SQLite → S3, migrating Milvus collections.
	3.	ObservabilityAdapter
	•	Purpose: Binds OpenTelemetry (OTEL) instrumentation to all modules. Exports:
• Span metrics for every gRPC call (RSM, LLM, vector search)
• Business metrics (code generation success rate, test pass rate)
• Syncs to Prometheus/Grafana/​Jaeger.
	4.	PluginLoaderAdapter
	•	Purpose: Manages dynamic loading of Nx-style plugins (npm packages under plugins/ or external repos).
	•	Mechanism:
• Uses Chokidar to watch file changes
• Validates plugin.json manifest via Zod (requires name, version, capabilities, commands, configSchema)
• Installs plugins (npm link or pnpm workspace protocol), publishes their capabilities to the registry, and wires up event hooks (e.g., a plugin might register a new Agent or override an existing adapter).
	5.	ReflexionAdapter
	•	Purpose: Implements the Reflexion State Machine (RSM).
	•	Responsibilities:
• Publishes events (e.g., ModelSwitched, AgentError, PlanStuck, UserFeedbackReceived) onto a gRPC streaming topic.
• Provides a Node.js EventEmitter fallback for single-process environments.
• Stores event logs in LevelDB/SQLite for replay on restart (durable event log).
• Triggers self-healing workflows via Keptn based on certain event patterns (e.g., repeated test failures).

3. Nx Backbone & Development Workflow

3.1 Why Nx?
	•	Monorepo Orchestration: Nx v16 organizes code into apps/, libs/, tools/ and manages implicit dependencies.
	•	Distributed Caching: Nx Cloud or local caching speeds up rebuilds, tests, and e2e across the workspace.
	•	Generators & Executors: Prebuilt Nx generators (@nrwl/js, @nrwl/node, @nrwl/vitest, @nrwl/jest, @nrwl/playwright, @nrwl/cypress) accelerate scaffolding for new libraries, apps, and test suites.
	•	TypeScript Project References: Ensures correct build ordering ("composite": true) without reinventing wheel.

4. Non-Functional & Cross-Cutting Concerns

4.1 Security & Compliance
	•	Authentication: OAuth2 (Auth Code + PKCE) for user-driven actions; Client Credentials Grant for M2M. JWT tokens signed with RS256, short TTL.
	•	Authorization: RBAC with roles (admin, developer, viewer), enforced via NestJS guards (@nrwl/nest:guard).
	•	Data Protection: AES-256-GCM encryption at rest for sensitive data (e.g., DB fields). TLS for all gRPC/HTTP endpoints via Cert-Manager + Let’s Encrypt.
	•	Supply-Chain Security:
	•	Sigstore / Rekor for verifying container images.
	•	SLSA Level 3 attestation for build artifacts.
	•	OPA policies in CI to block unapproved package sources.

4.2 Observability & Monitoring
	•	Metrics (Prometheus)
	•	Agent metrics (nootropic_agent_requests_total, nootropic_agent_errors_total)
	•	LLM inference latency (nootropic_inference_latency_ms{model="starcoder2"})
	•	Vector store ops (nootropic_vector_ops_total)
	•	Quota usage (nootropic_quota_usage{userId="…"})
	•	Tracing (Jaeger via OpenTelemetry)
	•	Trace spans for each gRPC call, each LLM request (ModelAdapter.invoke()), each vector query (StorageAdapter.query()), and critical Nx tasks (nx build, nx test).
	•	Logging (Pino / Winston)
	•	Structured JSON logs ({timestamp, level, service, message, metadata...}) aggregated by Fluentd or Loki.
	•	Alerting (Grafana + Alertmanager)
	•	Thresholds on high error rates (>1 %), high latency (>95th percentile > 500 ms), high resource usage (CPU/RAM > 80 %).
	•	On SLO breach (e.g., CI failure > 3 consecutive builds), Keptn triggers LitmusChaos or automated rollback.

4.3 Performance & Scalability
	•	Local Developer Performance
	•	Nx’s distributed caching: rebuilding only changed projects; caching test results.
	•	Vitest for unit tests (100 ms per suite), Playwright for basic e2e (< 2 s).
	•	Inference Performance
	•	Local quantized LLMs (e.g., llama.cpp Q4) run at ~50 ms/token on midrange GPUs; fallback CPU at 200 ms/token.
	•	Petals cluster for very large models (e.g., Llama 3 70 B) using P2P inference.
	•	Vector Search Performance
	•	Chroma HNSW index: < 50 ms for 1 M vectors; LanceDB on‐disk: < 100 ms.
	•	Horizontal Scaling
	•	Agents deployed as Kubernetes Deployments with HPA (CPU/memory thresholds).
	•	Vector stores (Milvus) run as StatefulSet with GPU nodes.
	•	Redis, PostgreSQL run as managed clusters or via helm charts (Nx custom executors manage deployments).

5. Development Roadmap Alignment

Based on everything above and the existing roadmap (short, medium, long-term from MASTER_BRIEF), here is how the priorities align:
	1.	Weeks 0–2: Bootstrap
	•	Nx workspace scaffold, core library generation (shared, runtime, ui)
	•	Stand up Chroma, set up ModelAdapter for local inference (Ollama + llama.cpp)
	•	Basic VS Code extension and CLI scaffolding via Nx generators
	2.	Weeks 3–4: Quality & Security
	•	Integrate Semgrep and OpenRewrite into CriticAgent (Nx Jest, Vitest, SonarCloud)
	•	Add GitHub Actions using Nx’s affected pipelines, enforce lint, typecheck, static analysis
	3.	Weeks 5–6: Self-Healing CI/CD
	•	Deploy Temporal server (Nx app) + Keptn (Docker Compose)
	•	On build/test failure, Keptn triggers LitmusChaos experiments and can rollback to last good branch via GitOps
	4.	Weeks 7–8: Learning Loop
	•	Instrument FeedbackAgent to collect acceptance rates; schedule nightly LoRA fine-tuning via Temporal (Tabby ML jobs)
	•	Build benchmarking scripts (tools/benchmark) and compare model throughput
	5.	Quarter 2+: Autonomous Expansion
	•	Spin up OpenDevin-style ReasoningAgent for long-horizon tasks (architecture migrations, multi-repo refactors)
	•	Launch plugin marketplace (hosted on GitHub) and steward community contributions

6. Key Takeaways on Current State
	•	Nx Integration: Nootropic is now fully Nx-driven: every agent, adapter, UI, and tool is an Nx project with clearly defined targets (build, test, lint, serve). Implicit dependencies ensure that building a consumer library always builds its dependencies (e.g., model-adapter depends on shared and runtime). Distributed caching and incremental builds drastically speed up development iterations.
	•	Agent/Adapter Ecosystem: All core capabilities—planning, coding, critiquing, reasoning, searching, feedback, project management, explainability, memory, observability—are implemented as separate Nx libraries or apps, exposing gRPC endpoints and registering themselves in the Capability Registry. Adapters (ModelAdapter, StorageAdapter, ObservabilityAdapter, PluginLoaderAdapter, ReflexionAdapter) provide the glue between agents and external services (LLM backends, vector stores, telemetry, plugin discovery).
	•	Data Flow & Self-Healing: User → CLI/VS Code/Electron → Capability Registry → Orchestrator (Temporal + RxJS) → Agents <→ Adapters → Inference/Vector Stores/Storage → Observability → Keptn → Recovery. Telemetry and events travel through ReflexionAdapter, enabling closed-loop self-healing.
	•	Free-First, Extensible Model Management: The ModelAdapter chooses between local quantized models (Ollama, llama.cpp, Tabby ML) and cloud providers (OpenAI, Anthropic) based on hardware and user preferences. A JSON-driven Model Registry (with Zod validation) ensures consistent metadata, and fallback routing keeps performance predictable.
	•	Comprehensive RAG Layer: SearchAgent uses Chroma for in-process, LanceDB for on-disk, and Milvus/Weaviate for large scale. Chunking strategies, embedding pipelines, and incremental indexing (Chokidar watchers) let agents retrieve relevant context for LLM prompts.
	•	Observability & Security: OpenTelemetry instrumentation in each component feeds Jaeger and Prometheus, enabling Grafana dashboards, Keptn remediation flows, and SLO enforcement. Security is enforced via OAuth2/JWT, RBAC, OPA policies, SLSA supply-chain measures, and data encryption.
	•	Developer Experience: Nx generators, VS Code configurations, CLI scaffolding, and Electron dashboards all work in concert—making onboarding (via nootropic wizard) possible in under 2 minutes, while enabling power users to script custom workflows.

	5.	Nightly LoRA Pipeline: Run a small LoRA fine-tune cycle on an open-source dataset (e.g., Code-Parrots), then compare inference performance/accuracy against a baseline.

By systematically verifying these core paths—agent communication, RAG retrieval, plugin loading, self-healing, and learning loops—we ensure that nootropic’s foundational pillars are rock solid. From there, performance optimizations (benchmarking scripts, Telemetry tuning), expanded plugin ecosystem, and enterprise features (multi-tenant vector stores, advanced RBAC) can be layered on with confidence.

  > **NOTE**: This is the canonical technical specification document for the Nootropic project. It serves as the single source of truth for all technical details, specifications, and implementation guidelines.
+ 
+ ## Executive Summary
+ 
+ Nootropic is a free-first, open-source-first AI/LLM-driven development environment and platform. Its chief aims are to provide developers with:
+ 
+ 1. Advanced, dynamic project planning and management, through autonomous agents that decompose high-level intent into tasks, track state, and adjust plans in real time.
+ 2. Deep code assistance and generation, leveraging local or cloud LLMs seamlessly (ModelAdapter) and integrating static analysis for continuous feedback (CriticAgent).
+ 3. Rich RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) capabilities, using vector stores like Chroma/LanceDB/Milvus/Weaviate so agents can query large code/document corpora without context window limits.
+ 4. Self-healing and self-teaching loops, where telemetry from LLM calls, CI/CD pipelines, and user feedback feed nightly fine-tuning (LoRA) and automated remediation (Keptn + LitmusChaos).
+ 5. A unified user experience across CLI, VS Code extension, and Electron UI, where slash commands or wizard flows guide users through scaffolding, coding, searching, debugging, and deployment—all orchestrated under Nx's monorepo.
+ 
+ Through modular micro-services (stateless containers and gRPC contracts), strong data-sovereign defaults (all code, embeddings, telemetry stay local unless explicitly opted into cloud), and a registry-driven plugin system, nootropic aspires to be the leanest yet most intelligent environment for AI-augmented software development.
+ 
+ ## Core Principles
+ 
+ ### 1. Free-First, Opt-In Cloud
+ - **Local-First Inference**: Default to locally quantized models (Ollama, llama.cpp, Tabby ML, vLLM, Exllama) for cost-free, privacy-preserving usage.
+ - **Cloud Fallback**: Users may opt into premium cloud LLMs (OpenAI, Anthropic, Google) via simple configuration—without sacrificing a baseline fully-offline experience.
+ 
+ ### 2. Modular, Extensible Micro-Services
+ - Each capability (planning, coding, search, storage, observability) is packaged as a stateless container or Nx library target, communicating over gRPC + Protobuf and streaming event buses (ReflexionAdapter).
+ - Agents register themselves in a Capability Registry so that CLI/VS Code/Electron can discover and invoke them dynamically.
+ 
+ ### 3. Data-Sovereign by Default
+ - All code, embeddings, telemetry, and agent traces are stored locally (ChromaDB, LanceDB, SQLite/LevelDB, Prometheus/Grafana on-prem).
+ - No external data egress unless the user configures ModelAdapter to route to cloud or shares telemetry.
+ 
+ ### 4. Self-Awareness & Self-Healing
+ - Agents emit structured traces/logs that feed into telemetry (OpenTelemetry → Jaeger → Grafana).
+ - Keptn watches SLOs and Prometheus metrics; if a critical failure is detected, it can roll back or trigger a LitmusChaos experiment.
+ - Continuous feedback is logged for nightly LoRA fine-tuning of local models, gradually improving suggestion accuracy without cloud spend.
+ 
+ ### 5. Declarative Goals & Autonomous Execution
+ - Developers state high-level intent in a project-spec.yaml. The ProjectMgrAgent translates that into PDDL, generates a task graph, and schedules tasks.
+ - Agents coordinate via a blackboard (vector + graph DB). Through a Reflexion Loop, they converge on working pull requests with minimal manual intervention.
+ 
+ ### 6. Unified UX in IDE + CLI + Desktop
+ - VS Code Extension exposes slash commands for coding, planning, testing, and deployment.
+ - CLI offers registry-driven commands for all operations.
+ - Electron Dashboard provides Kanban boards, trace viewers, and real-time metrics/alerts.
  
  ## Table of Contents

+ #### 1.3.1 Why Nx?
+ - **Monorepo Orchestration**: Nx v16 organizes code into apps/, libs/, tools/ and manages implicit dependencies
+ - **Distributed Caching**: Nx Cloud or local caching speeds up rebuilds, tests, and e2e across the workspace
+ - **Generators & Executors**: Prebuilt Nx generators accelerate scaffolding for new libraries, apps, and test suites
+ - **TypeScript Project References**: Ensures correct build ordering without reinventing wheel

2. Priority Areas
	1.	Core Agent System Implementation
	•	Reason: Agents form the “brains” of nootropic. Without a solid PlannerAgent, CoderAgent, CriticAgent, ReasoningAgent, SearchAgent, etc., nothing else can function.
	•	Key Deliverables:
	•	Finalize Protobuf/gRPC contracts for each agent’s inputs and outputs.
	•	Scaffold each agent as an Nx library under libs/agents/…, ensuring correct TypeScript references, build targets, and implicit dependencies.
	•	Hook up ReflexionAdapter so agents publish and subscribe to event streams (e.g., PlanUpdated, CodeFixApplied).
	2.	RAG & Vector Store Integration
	•	Reason: Retrieval-Augmented Generation underpins context-rich code suggestions. Agents need fast, scalable access to embeddings.
	•	Key Deliverables:
	•	Deploy a local ChromaDB instance (Nx project “chroma” with Docker Compose) and implement the VectorStoreAdapter library to wrap Chroma, with LanceDB fallback once data grows.
	•	Wire SearchAgent to embed code/doc chunks (using ModelAdapter) and query the vector store in under 50 ms per lookup.
	•	Validate end-to-end: CoderAgent pulls relevant context via RAG ⇒ feeds into LLM prompt.
	3.	Plugin System Development
	•	Reason: Extensibility via third-party plugins (new agents, adapters, UI widgets) is a core tenet. A robust plugin framework prevents future rework.
	•	Key Deliverables:
	•	Complete PluginLoaderAdapter under libs/adapters/plugin-loader. It should watch plugins/, validate plugin.json with Zod, install/link plugins via PNPM workspace, and update the Capability Registry (.nootropic-cache/describe-registry.json).
	•	Ensure CLI, VS Code, and Electron read from the registry and surface plugin-provided commands/menus dynamically.
	4.	Self-Healing Capabilities
	•	Reason: One of nootropic’s unique differentiators is automated recovery (CI pipelines, LLM outages, service failures). Early integration proves that resilience.
	•	Key Deliverables:
	•	Stand up Keptn + LitmusChaos (Nx Docker Compose or K8s Helm) and configure it to watch Prometheus metrics (e.g., high test failure rates, latency SLO breaches).
	•	Instrument agents and adapters with OpenTelemetry so that ReflexionAdapter events and metrics can trigger Keptn remediation flows (e.g., restart service, rollback code).
	•	Demonstrate an automated rollback on a deliberately failing CI job.
	5.	Learning & Adaptation Mechanisms
	•	Reason: To continuously improve suggestion quality, nootropic must learn from user feedback (accepted vs. rejected patches) via nightly LoRA fine-tuning.
	•	Key Deliverables:
	•	Implement FeedbackAgent to capture (prompt, response, feedback) tuples and store them in MemoryAgent (Chroma/LanceDB).
	•	Design a Temporal workflow that runs nightly, reads accepted diffs, generates LoRA training data, and kicks off a Tabby ML or vLLM fine-tune job.
	•	Integrate benchmark scripts under tools/benchmark to measure pre- and post-fine-tuning model accuracy and inference latency.
	6.	Performance Optimization
	•	Reason: Even on consumer-grade hardware, all agents and adapters must be snappy—builds under 2 s, inference sub-100 ms (small models), vector queries under 50 ms.
	•	Key Deliverables:
	•	Leverage Nx’s distributed caching to minimize rebuild times and test runs (nx affected:build, nx affected:test).
	•	Profile CPU/GPU utilization (Clinic JS, Chrome DevTools CPU profiles) and optimize hot paths in ModelAdapter (e.g., using llama.cpp Q4 quantization).
	•	Instrument OpenTelemetry traces for each LLM call and vector query; visualize in Grafana to identify bottlenecks.

⸻

3. Resource Constraints
	1.	Hardware Requirements for Local Model Inference
	•	GPU Availability: Many users will have a single midrange GPU (e.g., NVIDIA GTX 1660 Ti or equivalent). ModelAdapter must detect CUDA vs. ROCm vs. CPU-only and pick appropriate quantized models (e.g., starcoder2-q4_0).
	•	Memory Footprint: Recommend ≥ 8 GB RAM and ≥ 20 GB free SSD. Small (7 B) models can run on 8 GB RAM. Larger (34 B) models require ≥ 16 GB RAM or P2P inference via Petals/HuggingFace.
	•	Disk Storage: Embedding indexes (Chroma + LanceDB) and vector snapshots may consume tens of GB. At least 50 GB SSD recommended.
	2.	Cloud Infrastructure Availability
	•	On-Premise vs. Cloud: Base functionality must run fully on-prem using local models (Ollama, llama.cpp, Tabby ML). Only opt into cloud (OpenAI, Anthropic, HF) if local hardware cannot meet performance.
	•	CI Runners: GitHub Actions runners have limited memory (7 GB RAM) and CPU. We must use Nx’s affected:… commands to avoid spinning up full stacks for every change. Remote caching (Nx Cloud) is crucial to speed up builds/tests.
	3.	Development Team Size & Expertise
	•	Assume a small core team (2–3 engineers) initially: one focusing on agent implementation (TypeScript, gRPC, PDDL), another on adapters/integration (vector store, LLM routing), and a third on infrastructure/CI/CD (Nx, Docker/K8s, Keptn).
	•	Leverage existing expertise in Nx monorepos to avoid reinventing build/test pipelines.
	4.	Timeline Expectations
	•	Short-Term (Next 2 Weeks):
	•	Bootstrap Nx workspace, scaffold core agents and adapters, deploy Chroma, implement basic ModelAdapter for local LLMs.
	•	Mid-Term (1–2 Months):
	•	Complete CriticAgent with Semgrep/OpenRewrite, integrate Self-Healing (Keptn), implement FeedbackAgent and nightly LoRA pipelines.
	•	Long-Term (3–6 Months):
	•	Harden plugin ecosystem, add multi-repo vector store support (Milvus/Weaviate), refine performance optimizations, publish an initial v1.0 release.

⸻

4. Integration Requirements
	1.	Version Control Systems
	•	GitHub / GitLab / Azure DevOps:
	•	CI/CD via GitHub Actions (or equivalent) running Nx pipelines (nx affected:build, nx affected:test, nx affected:e2e).
	•	Enable Dependabot or Renovate for dependency updates, and CodeQL for deep security analysis.
	2.	CI/CD Pipelines
	•	Nx + GitHub Actions Integration:
	•	Define .github/workflows/ci.yml to run:
	1.	npm ci (PNPM install)
	2.	nx affected:build
	3.	nx affected:test --codeCoverage
	4.	nx affected:e2e (Playwright/Cypress)
	5.	nx affected:lint
	6.	Upload coverage to Codecov.
	•	Use Nx Cloud or local remote caching to accelerate subsequent runs.
	3.	Monitoring & Observability Systems
	•	Prometheus + Grafana + Jaeger:
	•	Each agent/adapter (ModelAdapter, SearchAgent, CriticAgent) is instrumented with OpenTelemetry. OTLP exporter sends traces to Jaeger; metrics scraped by Prometheus.
	•	Grafana dashboards visualize:
	•	LLM inference latency (nootropic_inference_latency_ms)
	•	Vector search throughput (nootropic_vector_ops_total)
	•	Reflexion event queue depth (nootropic_event_queue_depth)
	•	Service health (error rates, CPU/memory usage).
	4.	External LLM Providers
	•	OpenAI / Anthropic / Google Vertex AI:
	•	Opt-in via ModelAdapter configuration (~/.nootropic/config.json or environment variables).
	•	Implement exponential backoff and retry logic for failed requests.
	•	Track cloud usage in ObservabilityAdapter (nootropic_cloud_cost_usd_total).
	•	HuggingFace / Petals / LM Studio / Ollama / Tabby ML / Local.AI:
	•	Default to local quantized models (Ollama, llama.cpp via ModelAdapter).
	•	If local hardware is insufficient (detected via GPU capabilities), fallback to Petals or HuggingFace inference endpoints, respecting user’s budget and latency preferences.
	5.	Vector Database Providers
	•	ChromaDB (primary local): Built into the repo as a Docker Compose service.
	•	LanceDB (local on-disk): Fallback when Chroma’s in-memory index grows beyond thresholds.
	•	Milvus / Weaviate (optional cluster or multi-tenant setups): Support for large-scale corpora across multiple projects; Nx can launch a Kubernetes cluster or Docker Compose service for Milvus in staging/​production.

⸻

5. Success Metrics
	1.	Response Times (Latency)
	•	LLM Inference:
	•	Small, local quantized models (7 B parameters) should respond at < 100 ms per token on GPU.
	•	If fallback to CPU mode, aim for < 500 ms per token using Q4 quantization.
	•	Cloud LLMs (GPT-4) should respond in < 1 s per token.
	•	Vector Search:
	•	Chroma (HNSW) lookups < 50 ms for 100 k-vector corpus.
	•	LanceDB on-disk queries < 100 ms.
	•	CLI/UI Operations:
	•	Basic CLI commands (nootropic plan, nootropic code) should start within 200 ms and show interactive prompts within 500 ms.
	•	VS Code slash commands (/code, /search) should yield first suggestions under 300 ms.
	2.	Code Generation Quality
	•	Human-Rated Accuracy: On a scale of 1–5, average user rating for generated code should be ≥ 4.0 in beta.
	•	Automated Test Pass Rate: Generated code should pass ≥ 90 % of auto-generated unit tests for scaffolded projects.
	•	Static Analysis False Positives: After CriticAgent’s Semgrep/OpenRewrite run, false positives should be < 10 % of flagged issues.
	3.	System Reliability & Availability
	•	Uptime: ≥ 99.9 % for critical services (ModelAdapter, SearchAgent, CriticAgent).
	•	Error Rate:
	•	Keep nootropic_api_errors_total / nootropic_api_requests_total under 1 %.
	•	For self-healing scenarios, any failed LLM service call should recover within 30 s via fallback or retry.
	4.	User Satisfaction
	•	Net Promoter Score (NPS): Target NPS ≥ 50 among early adopters.
	•	Time to Onboard: New users should be able to run nootropic wizard and scaffold a working project (with CI, tests, basic agents) under 2 minutes.
	•	User Retention: ≥ 75 % of users who try nootropic in the first week should return to use it again within 30 days.
	5.	Resource Efficiency & Cost
	•	Local Resource Usage:
	•	CPU utilization for inference < 50 % on an 8 GB RAM, 4-core machine when running a 7 B Q4 model.
	•	Memory usage < 8 GB for 7 B model.
	•	Cloud Cost:
	•	Monthly spend on cloud LLMs (OpenAI, Anthropic) should remain < $200 for a developer running typical workloads (500 k tokens/month).
	•	CI/CD Efficiency:
	•	Nx’s distributed caching should reduce build/test times by ≥ 50 % on repeated runs.
	•	Aim for end-to-end CI pipeline (build → test → lint → e2e) to complete under 10 minutes on GitHub Actions.

⸻

In summary, the first order of business is delivering a working core agent ecosystem and RAG layer, while simultaneously putting in place a robust plugin framework. Resource constraints—especially local GPU/CPU limits and CI runner capacity—must guide choices around model selection and CI configuration. Integration with GitHub Actions, Prometheus/Grafana, Keptn, and external LLM APIs is non-negotiable. Finally, success will be measured by latency, code quality, uptime, user satisfaction, and cost efficiency—ensuring nootropic remains performant, reliable, and free-first.

  ## Overview
  
- The nootropic API provides programmatic access to core AI‐driven functionality, including chat/completion, embeddings generation, and vector store queries. All endpoints are prefixed with `/v1/` and accept JSON payloads. Responses are also returned in JSON.
+ The nootropic API provides programmatic access to core AI‐driven functionality, with a focus on local-first operations. All endpoints are prefixed with `/v1/` and accept JSON payloads. Responses are also returned in JSON.
  
- > **See Also**: [Architecture Overview](../ARCHITECTURE.md#api-architecture) for detailed API design.
- 
- ## Authentication
- 
- All API calls require an API key. By default, the key is stored in a local configuration file (`~/.nootropic/config.json`) under the `apiKey` field.
- 
- > **See Also**: [Security Configuration](../SECURITY.md#api-security) for security best practices.
- 
- ### Obtaining an API Key
- 
- 1. Run `npx nootropic wizard` and follow prompts to generate or retrieve a local API key.
- 2. For cloud usage (e.g., hosted inference), sign up on the nootropic portal, navigate to "API Keys," and copy the key.
- 3. Store the key in `~/.nootropic/config.json`:
+ ## Local Configuration
+ 
+ ### Configuration File
+ 
+ The configuration file is stored locally at `~/.nootropic/config.json`:
  
  ```jsonc
  {
-   "apiKey": "YOUR_API_KEY_HERE",
- }
- ```
- 
- ### Using the API Key
- 
- Include the API key in all HTTP requests either as a header or query parameter:
- 
- - **Header:**
- 
-   ```http
-   Authorization: Bearer <API_KEY>
-   ```
- 
- - **Query Parameter** (not recommended for production):
- 
-   ```http
-   GET /v1/chat/completions?api_key=<API_KEY>
-   ```
- 
- ### API Key Management
- 
- #### Key Types
- 
- 1. **Development Keys**
-    - Limited rate limits
-    - Local development only
-    - No production access
- 
- 2. **Production Keys**
-    - Higher rate limits
-    - Full API access
-    - Usage monitoring
- 
- 3. **Service Keys**
-    - Highest rate limits
-    - Service-to-service
-    - IP restrictions
- 
- > **See Also**: [Security Best Practices](../SECURITY.md#key-management) for key management guidelines.
- 
- #### Key Rotation
- 
- 1. **Automatic Rotation**
-    - 90-day expiration
-    - Email notifications
-    - Grace period
- 
- 2. **Manual Rotation**
-    - On-demand rotation
-    - Emergency rotation
-    - Key revocation
- 
- #### Key Permissions

- 1. **Scopes**

-    - `chat:write`
-    - `embeddings:read`
-    - `vector:read`
-    - `vector:write`
-    - `models:read`
-    - `webhooks:manage`

-            except RateLimitError as e:
-                if attempt == retries - 1:
-                    raise
-                delay = base_delay * (2 ** attempt)
-                time.sleep(delay)

- ### Implementation
- 
- ```python
- def paginate_results(endpoint, params=None):
-     results = []
-     cursor = None
- 
-     while True:
-         if cursor:
-             params['cursor'] = cursor
- 
-         response = api.get(endpoint, params=params)
-         results.extend(response['data'])
- 
-         if not response.get('has_more'):
-             break
- 
-         cursor = response['next_cursor']
- 
-     return results

- ## Best Practices
- 
- ### Error Handling
- 
- 1. **Retry Logic**
- 
-    - Implement exponential backoff
-    - Handle rate limits
-    - Retry on network errors
-    - Log retry attempts
- 
- 2. **Error Types**
-    - API errors
-    - Network errors
-    - Validation errors
-    - Authentication errors
- 
- ### Performance Optimization
- 
- 1. **Caching**
- 
-    - Cache embeddings
-    - Cache model responses
-    - Cache vector queries
-    - Implement TTL
- 
- 2. **Batching**
-    - Batch embeddings
-    - Batch vector queries
-    - Batch completions
-    - Optimize batch size
+ // Optimize vector store
+ await nootropic.vector_store.optimize({
+   rebuild_index: true,
+   cleanup: true
+ });
+ 
+ // Optimize resource usage
+ await nootropic.resources.optimize({
+   threads: 4,
+   memory: '8GB',
+   gpu_layers: 32
+ });
+ ```
  
  ### Security Considerations
  
- 1. **API Key Security**
- 
-    - Rotate keys regularly
-    - Use environment variables
-    - Implement key scoping
-    - Monitor key usage
- 
- 2. **Data Security**
-    - Encrypt sensitive data
-    - Validate input
-    - Sanitize output
-    - Implement rate limiting
+ ```typescript
+ // Secure local storage
+ await nootropic.storage.secure({
+   encryption: true,
+   access_control: true
+ });
+ 
+ // Secure model inference
+ await nootropic.inference.secure({
+   input_validation: true,
+   output_sanitization: true
+ });
+ 
+ // Secure plugin system
+ await nootropic.plugins.secure({

+ });
+ ```

- ## Endpoints
- 
- ### 1. `/v1/chat/completions`
- 
- Generate chat‐style completions (similar to ChatGPT) or instruct the model to perform specific tasks (e.g., code generation). Supports streaming and non‐streaming modes.
- 
- **Request**
- 
- - Method: `POST`
- - URL: `/v1/chat/completions`
- - Headers:
-   - `Content-Type: application/json`
-   - `Authorization: Bearer <API_KEY>`
- 
- **Body Schema (`CompletionRequest`)**
- 
- ```jsonc
- {
-   "model": "string",                 // Required. Model identifier, e.g., "starcoder2-3b-4bit" or "openai:gpt-4o"
-   "messages": [                       // Required. Array of message objects
-     {
-       "role": "system" | "user" | "assistant",
-       "content": "string"
-     }
-   ],
-   "temperature": 0.0,                 // Optional. Sampling temperature (0.0–1.0). Default: 0.2
-   "top_p": 1.0,                       // Optional. Nucleus sampling parameter (0.0–1.0). Default: 1.0
-   "max_tokens": 1024,                 // Optional. Maximum tokens in response. Default: 512
-   "stream": false,                    // Optional. If true, enables streaming responses. Default: false
-   "stop": ["string"],                 // Optional. One or more stop sequences
-   "presence_penalty": 0.0,            // Optional. Encourages new topics. Range: –2.0 to 2.0. Default: 0.0
-   "frequency_penalty": 0.0,           // Optional. Penalizes repeated phrases. Range: –2.0 to 2.0. Default: 0.0
-   "user": "string"                    // Optional. Identifier for end‐user (for analytics)
- }
- ```
- 
- **Response**
- 
- - Status Codes:
-   - `200 OK`: Request succeeded
-   - `400 Bad Request`: Missing or invalid parameters
-   - `401 Unauthorized`: Invalid or missing API key
-   - `429 Too Many Requests`: Rate limit exceeded
-   - `500 Internal Server Error`: Model or server error
- 
- **Non‐Streaming Response Schema (`CompletionResponse`)**
- 
- ```jsonc
- {
-   "id": "string",                    // Unique ID for this completion request
-   "object": "chat.completion",       // Type of object returned
-   "created": 1623855600,             // Unix timestamp (seconds) of creation
-   "model": "string",                 // Model identifier used
-   "choices": [
+ ```typescript

+ ## Endpoints
+ 
+ ### 1. /v1/local/inference
+ 
+ ```http
+ POST /v1/local/inference
+ Content-Type: application/json
+ 
  {
-       "index": 0,
-       "message": {
-         "role": "assistant",
-         "content": "string"          // Generated content
-       },
-       "finish_reason": "stop" | "length" | "token_limit"
-     }
-     // ...more choices if `n` > 1 specified
-   ],
-   "usage": {
-     "prompt_tokens": 32,             // Number of tokens in the prompt
-     "completion_tokens": 48,         // Number of tokens generated
-     "total_tokens": 80               // Sum of prompt + completion tokens
-   }
- }
- ```
- 
- **Streaming Response**
- 
- If `"stream": true` in the request, the server returns a `text/event-stream` response. Each line prefixed with `data:` contains a JSON chunk:
- 
- ```
- data: {"id":"...","object":"chat.completion.chunk","created":...,"model":"...","choices":[{"delta":{"content":"Hello"},"index":0,"finish_reason":null}]}
- data: {"id":"...","object":"chat.completion.chunk","created":...,"model":"...","choices":[{"delta":{"content":" world"},"index":0,"finish_reason":"stop"}]}
+   "model": {
+     "name": "starcoder2-3b",
+     "version": "1.0.0",
+     "quantization": "4bit"
+   },
+   "prompt": "Complete this code:",
+   "max_tokens": 100,
+   "temperature": 0.7
+ }
  ```
  
- A final `data: [DONE]` line indicates completion.

- ### 3. `/v1/vector/query`
- 
- Query the vector store (Chroma by default) to find nearest neighbors for a given embedding or raw text (which is embedded internally).
- 
- **Request**
- 
- - Method: `POST`
- - URL: `/v1/vector/query`
- - Headers:
-   - `Content-Type: application/json`
-   - `Authorization: Bearer <API_KEY>`
- 
- **Body Schema (`VectorQueryRequest`)**
- 
- ```jsonc
+ ### 4. /v1/models
+ 
+ ```http
+ GET /v1/models
+ Content-Type: application/json
+ 
  {
-   "namespace": "string",             // Optional. Logical namespace in the vector store (default: "default")
-   "top_k": 10,                        // Optional. Number of nearest neighbors to return (default: 10)
-   "query_embedding": [0.01, 0.02, ... ],  // Either provide this or omit to use `query_text`
-   "query_text": "string",             // If provided, the server computes embedding before querying
-   "filters": {                        // Optional. Metadata filters (e.g., {"projectID": "projA"})
-     "projectID": "string",
-     "tags": ["string"]
-   },
-   "include_values": false,            // Optional. If true, return stored vectors in response (default: false)
-   "include_metadata": true            // Optional. If true, include metadata in results (default: true)
- }
- ```
- 
- > **Note:** Either `query_embedding` or `query_text` must be provided; if both are present, `query_embedding` takes precedence.
- 
- **Response**
- 
- - Status Codes:

-   - `400 Bad Request`
-   - `401 Unauthorized`
-   - `429 Too Many Requests`
-   - `500 Internal Server Error`
-

-   "results": [

-       "values"?: [0.01, -0.02, ...], // Optional. Stored vector (if `include_values: true`)
-       "metadata"?: {                 // Optional. Associated metadata (if `include_metadata: true`)

  ## Data Schemas
  
- Below are shared schema definitions used by multiple endpoints.
- 
- ### 1. `CompletionRequest`
- 
- ```jsonc
- {
-   "model": "string",
-   "messages": [

- ## Error Codes & Handling
- 
- All endpoints return standard HTTP status codes. The response body for error cases follows this schema:
- 
- ```jsonc
- {
-   "error": {
-     "code": "string",           // e.g., "invalid_request", "unauthorized", "rate_limit_exceeded"
-     "message": "string",        // Human-readable explanation
-     "details"?: [               // Optional. Array of validation errors or sub-errors
-       {
-         "field": "string",      // Name of the invalid parameter or field
-         "issue": "string"       // Description of the issue
-       }
-     ]
+ ### Error Handling
+ 
+ ```typescript
+ class NootropicError extends Error {
+   constructor(
+     public type: ErrorType,
+     public message: string,
+     public details?: Record<string, any>
+   ) {
+     super(message);
+   }
+ }
+ 
+ // Error handling example
+ try {
+   await nootropic.inference.complete({
+     prompt: 'Complete this code:',
+     max_tokens: 100
+   });
+ } catch (error) {
+   if (error instanceof NootropicError) {
+     switch (error.type) {
+       case ErrorType.RESOURCE_EXHAUSTED:
+         // Handle resource exhaustion
+         break;
+       case ErrorType.MODEL_NOT_FOUND:
+         // Handle missing model
+         break;
+       case ErrorType.VECTOR_STORE_ERROR:
+         // Handle vector store error
+         break;
+       default:
+         // Handle other errors
+         break;
+     }
    }
  }
  ```
- 
- **Common Error Codes**
- 
- - `400 Bad Request`
-   - `invalid_request`: Missing required field or invalid parameter type.
-   - `model_not_found`: Specified model ID is not recognized or supported.
-   - `invalid_stop_sequence`: Provided stop sequence conflicts with content.
- - `401 Unauthorized`
-   - `api_key_missing`: No Authorization header or api_key provided.
-   - `api_key_invalid`: Provided API key is invalid or expired.
- - `403 Forbidden`
-   - `model_access_denied`: API key does not have permission to access the requested model.
- - `404 Not Found`
-   - `resource_not_found`: For example, querying a vector namespace that doesn't exist.
- - `429 Too Many Requests`
-   - `rate_limit_exceeded`: Exceeded maximum requests per minute. Retry after the `Retry-After` header value (in seconds).
- - `500 Internal Server Error`
-   - `model_error`: Underlying model crashed or returned an unexpected response.
-   - `vector_store_error`: Unable to query or write to the vector database.
-

- ### 3. Vector Query (Python)
- 
- ```python
- import requests
- import os
- 
- API_URL = 'https://api.nootropic.ai/v1/vector/query'
- API_KEY = os.getenv('NOOTROPIC_API_KEY')
- 
- def query_vector_store(query_text):
-     # First, embed the query text
-     embed_resp = requests.post(
-         'https://api.nootropic.ai/v1/embeddings',
-         headers={
-             'Authorization': f'Bearer {API_KEY}',
-             'Content-Type': 'application/json'
-         },
-         json={
-             'model': 'openai-embeddings-001',
-             'input': query_text
-         }
-     )
-     embed_resp.raise_for_status()
-     embedding = embed_resp.json()['data'][0]['embedding']
- 
-     # Now perform the vector query
-     query_resp = requests.post(
-         API_URL,
-         headers={
-             'Authorization': f'Bearer {API_KEY}',
-             'Content-Type': 'application/json'
-         },
-         json={
-             'namespace': 'default',
-             'top_k': 5,
-             'query_embedding': embedding,
-             'include_metadata': True
-         }
-     )
-     query_resp.raise_for_status()
-     return query_resp.json()['results']
- 
- # Usage
- 
- results = query_vector_store('How to connect to Redis in Node.js?')
- for idx, item in enumerate(results):
-     print(f"Rank {idx+1}: ID={item['id']}, Score={item['score']}")
-     print(f"Metadata: {item.get('metadata')}\n")
- ```

  ## Versioning and Deprecation Policy
  
- - **Semantic Versioning:** All API changes follow SemVer. The version in use is implicitly tied to the CLI version installed (e.g., `nootropic@1.2.3` corresponds to v1 of the REST API).
- - **Deprecation Notice:** When an endpoint or field is scheduled for removal, a deprecation warning will appear in the response header:
- 
- ```
- Warning: 299 - "Deprecated API field 'stop' will be removed in v2.0"
- ```
- 
- \</rewritten_file>
+ ### Versioning
+ 
+ - Major version changes (v1 -> v2) indicate breaking changes
+ - Minor version changes (v1.0 -> v1.1) indicate new features
+ - Patch version changes (v1.0.0 -> v1.0.1) indicate bug fixes
+ 
+ ### Deprecation
+ 
+ - Features are marked as deprecated 6 months before removal
+ - Deprecated features continue to work for 6 months
+ - Breaking changes are announced 3 months in advance
+ - Migration guides are provided for all breaking changes
+ 
+ ### Migration
+ 
+ ```typescript
+ // Example migration from v1 to v2
+ const v1 = new NootropicV1();
+ const v2 = new NootropicV2();
+ 
+ // Migrate configuration
+ const config = await v1.getConfig();
+ await v2.setConfig(config);
+ 
+ // Migrate data
+ const data = await v1.getData();
+ await v2.setData(data);
+ 
+ // Migrate plugins
+ const plugins = await v1.getPlugins();
+ await v2.setPlugins(plugins);
+ ```

  ## Testing Strategy
  
- ### Test Configuration
- 
- 1. **Jest Configuration**
-    ```javascript
-    // jest.config.ts
-    export default {
-      displayName: 'nootropic-cli',
-      preset: '../../jest.preset.js',
-      testEnvironment: 'node',
-      transform: {
-        '^.+\\.[tj]s$': ['ts-jest', { tsconfig: '<rootDir>/tsconfig.spec.json' }]
-      },
-      moduleFileExtensions: ['ts', 'js', 'html'],
-      coverageDirectory: '../../coverage/apps/nootropic-cli',
-      collectCoverageFrom: [
-        'src/**/*.{ts,tsx}',
-        '!src/**/*.spec.{ts,tsx}',
-        '!src/**/*.test.{ts,tsx}',
-        '!src/**/*.e2e.{ts,tsx}'
-      ],
-      coverageThreshold: {
-        global: {
-          branches: 80,
-          functions: 80,
-          lines: 80,
-          statements: 80
-        }
-      }
-    };
-    ```
- 
- 2. **Playwright Configuration**
- ```typescript
-    // playwright.config.ts
-    import { defineConfig, devices } from '@playwright/test';
- 
-    export default defineConfig({
-      testDir: './e2e',
-      fullyParallel: true,
-      forbidOnly: !!process.env.CI,
-      retries: process.env.CI ? 2 : 0,
-      workers: process.env.CI ? 1 : undefined,
-      reporter: 'html',
-      use: {
-        baseURL: 'http://localhost:4200',
-        trace: 'on-first-retry',
-        video: 'on-first-retry'
-      },
-      projects: [
-        {
-          name: 'chromium',
-          use: { ...devices['Desktop Chrome'] }
-        },
-        {
-          name: 'firefox',
-          use: { ...devices['Desktop Firefox'] }
-        },
-        {
-          name: 'webkit',
-          use: { ...devices['Desktop Safari'] }
-        }
-      ],
-      webServer: {
-        command: 'nx serve nootropic-cli',
-        url: 'http://localhost:4200',
-        reuseExistingServer: !process.env.CI
-      }
-    });
-    ```
-

- ## Deployment
- 
- ### Deployment Configuration
- 
- 1. **Nx Build Configuration**
-    ```json
-    // project.json
-    {
-      "targets": {
-        "build": {
-          "executor": "@nx/vite:build",
-          "outputs": ["{options.outputPath}"],
-          "options": {
-            "outputPath": "dist/apps/nootropic-cli",
-            "main": "apps/nootropic-cli/src/main.ts",
-            "tsConfig": "apps/nootropic-cli/tsconfig.app.json",
-            "assets": ["apps/nootropic-cli/src/assets"],
-            "index": "apps/nootropic-cli/src/index.html",
-            "baseHref": "/",
-            "sourcemap": true,
-            "optimize": true
-          },
-          "configurations": {
-            "production": {
-              "mode": "production",
-              "sourcemap": false,
-              "minify": true,
-              "optimize": true
-            },
-            "staging": {
-              "mode": "staging",
-              "sourcemap": true,
-              "minify": true,
-              "optimize": true
-            }
-          }
-        }
-   }
- }
- ```
- 
- 2. **Docker Configuration**
-    ```dockerfile
-    # Dockerfile
-    FROM node:18-alpine AS builder
-    
-    WORKDIR /app
-    
-    # Install pnpm
-    RUN npm install -g pnpm
-    
-    # Copy package files
-    COPY package.json pnpm-lock.yaml ./
-    
-    # Install dependencies
-    RUN pnpm install --frozen-lockfile
-    
-    # Copy source code
-    COPY . .
-    
-    # Build application
-    RUN pnpm nx build nootropic-cli --configuration=production
-    
-    # Production image
-    FROM node:18-alpine
-    
-    WORKDIR /app
-    
-    # Copy built assets
-    COPY --from=builder /app/dist/apps/nootropic-cli ./dist
-    
-    # Copy package files
-    COPY package.json pnpm-lock.yaml ./
-    
-    # Install production dependencies
-    RUN pnpm install --prod --frozen-lockfile
-    
-    # Set environment variables
-    ENV NODE_ENV=production
-    
-    # Start application
-    CMD ["node", "dist/main.js"]
-    ```
- 
- 3. **Kubernetes Configuration**
-    ```yaml
-    # deployment.yaml
-    apiVersion: apps/v1
-    kind: Deployment
-    metadata:
-      name: nootropic-cli
-      namespace: production
-    spec:
-      replicas: 3
-      selector:
-        matchLabels:
-          app: nootropic-cli
-      template:
-        metadata:
-          labels:
-            app: nootropic-cli
-        spec:
-          containers:
-          - name: nootropic-cli
-            image: nootropic-cli:latest
-            ports:
-            - containerPort: 3000
-            resources:
-              requests:
-                cpu: "100m"
-                memory: "128Mi"
-              limits:
-                cpu: "500m"
-                memory: "512Mi"
-            env:
-            - name: NODE_ENV
-              valueFrom:
-                secretKeyRef:
-                  name: nx-cloud-secrets
-                  key: token
-    ```

- ### Common Solutions
- 
- 1. **Build Solutions**
-    - Clear cache
-      ```bash
-      # Clear Nx cache
-      nx reset
-      
-      # Clear specific project cache
-      nx reset --project=my-project
-      
-      # Clear all caches
-      nx reset --all
-      ```
-    - Update dependencies
-      ```bash
-      # Update all dependencies
-      pnpm update
-      
-      # Update specific dependency
-      pnpm update package-name
-      
-      # Update to latest version
-      pnpm update --latest
-      ```
-    - Rebuild project
-      ```bash
-      # Rebuild all projects
-      nx run-many --target=build --all
-      
-      # Rebuild specific project
-      nx build my-project
-      
-      # Rebuild with clean
-      nx build my-project --clean
-      ```
- 
- 2. **Development Solutions**
-    - Reset workspace
-      ```bash
-      # Reset workspace
-      nx reset
-      
-      # Reset specific project
-      nx reset --project=my-project
-      
-      # Reset all projects
-      nx reset --all
-      ```
-    - Update tools
-      ```bash
-      # Update Nx
-      pnpm update @nx/workspace
-      
-      # Update plugins
-      pnpm update @nx/react @nx/node
-      
-      # Update all tools
-      pnpm update --latest
-      ```
-    - Fix dependencies
-      ```bash
-      # Fix dependency issues
-      pnpm install --force
-      
-      # Clean install
-      pnpm install --clean
-      
-      # Update lockfile
-      pnpm install --no-frozen-lockfile
-      ```
- 
- 3. **Nx Cloud Solutions**
-    - Reset cloud cache
-      ```bash
-      # Reset cloud cache
-      nx cloud reset
-      
-      # Reset specific project
-      nx cloud reset --project=my-project
-      
-      # Reset all projects
-      nx cloud reset --all
-      ```
-    - Update cloud config
-      ```bash
-      # Update cloud config
-      nx g @nx/workspace:setup-nx-cloud
-      
-      # Update cloud token
-      nx cloud set-token
-      
-      # Update cloud URL
-      nx cloud set-url
-      ```
-    - Fix cloud issues
-      ```bash
-      # Fix cloud connection
-      nx cloud connect
-      
-      # Fix cloud sync
-      nx cloud sync
-      
-      # Fix cloud cache
-      nx cloud cache
-      ```

- ### Model Commands
- 
- #### `model:list`
- 
- List available models and their status.
- 
- ```sh
- npx nootropic model:list [options]
- ```
- 
- **Options:**
- - `--type <type>` Filter by model type (local, cloud, hybrid)
- - `--status <status>` Filter by model status (ready, downloading, error)
- - `--json` Output in JSON format
- 
- **Example:**
- ```sh
- npx nootropic model:list --type local --status ready
- ```
- 
- #### `model:download`
- 
- Download a model for local use.
- 
- ```sh
- npx nootropic model:download <model-id> [options]
- ```
- 
- **Options:**
- - `--quantization <type>` Specify quantization type (4-bit, 8-bit)
- - `--priority <level>` Set download priority (low, medium, high)
- - `--force` Force re-download if model exists
- 
- **Example:**
- ```sh
- npx nootropic model:download starcoder-2 --quantization 4-bit --priority high
- ```
- 
- #### `model:remove`
- 
- Remove a downloaded model.
- 
- ```sh
- npx nootropic model:remove <model-id> [options]
- ```
- 
- **Options:**
- - `--force` Skip confirmation prompt
- - `--keep-config` Keep model configuration
- 
- **Example:**
- ```sh
- npx nootropic model:remove starcoder-2 --force
- ```
- 
- ### Inference Commands
- 
- #### `inference:start`
- 
- Start local model inference.
- 
- ```sh
- npx nootropic inference:start <model-id> [options]
- ```
- 
- **Options:**
- - `--input <text>` Input text for inference
- - `--temperature <value>` Set temperature (0.0-1.0)
- - `--max-tokens <n>` Maximum tokens to generate
- - `--stream` Stream output in real-time
- 
- **Example:**
- ```sh
- npx nootropic inference:start starcoder-2 --input "Hello, world!" --temperature 0.7
- ```
- 
- #### `inference:stop`
- 
- Stop running inference.
- 
- ```sh
- npx nootropic inference:stop <inference-id> [options]
- ```
- 
- **Options:**
- - `--force` Force stop without cleanup
- - `--keep-output` Keep output files
- 
- **Example:**
- ```sh
- npx nootropic inference:stop inf-123 --force
- ```
-

  ### Common Errors
  
- - **Missing Configuration File**
- 
-   - Error: `Cannot find config file "~/.nootropic/config.json"`
-   - **Solution:** Run `npx nootropic wizard` to create a default config, or specify `--config <path>`.
- 
- - **Model Download Failures**
- 
-   - Error: `Failed to download model"starcoder2-3b-4bit"`
-   - **Solution:** Ensure you have sufficient disk space and a stable internet connection. Use `--model` to select a local or alternative model.
- 
- - **PDDL Solver Timeout**
- 
-   - Error: `Planning failed: solver timed out after 60s`
-   - **Solution:** Increase timeout via `npx nootropic plan --timeout 120`, or simplify the project spec to reduce complexity.
- 
- - **Indexing Errors**
- 
-   - Error: `Chroma index unreachable`
-   - **Solution:** Verify that the Chroma server is running (`docker ps`), and check `storageAdapter` config in `~/.nootropic/config.json`.
- 
- - **Permission Denied**
-   - Error: `EACCES: permission denied, access '<path>'`
-   - **Solution:** Adjust file or directory permissions, or run with elevated privileges.
- 
- For further assistance, consult the [documentation](https://github.com/your-org/nootropic/docs) or open an issue on the GitHub repository.
+ 1. **Memory Issues**
+    - Error: "Memory limit exceeded"
+    - Solution: Increase memory limit or optimize resource usage
+ 
+ 2. **CPU Issues**
+    - Error: "CPU limit exceeded"
+    - Solution: Increase CPU limit or optimize resource usage
+ 
+ 3. **Plugin Issues**
+    - Error: "Plugin not found"
+    - Solution: Check plugin path and installation
  
  ### Performance Issues
  
- - **Slow Command Execution**
- 
-   - **Symptoms:** Commands take longer than expected to complete
-   - **Solutions:**
-     - Check system resources (CPU, memory, disk)
-     - Verify network connectivity
-     - Clear cache: `npx nootropic config reset cache`
-     - Use `--verbose` for detailed timing information
- 
- - **High Memory Usage**
- 
-   - **Symptoms:** System becomes unresponsive during command execution
-   - **Solutions:**
-     - Increase system swap space
-     - Use smaller models with `--model` flag
-     - Split large operations into smaller tasks
-     - Monitor with `npx nootropic monitor --resources`
- 
- ### Network Issues
- 
- - **API Connection Failures**
- 
-   - **Error:** `Failed to connect to API endpoint`
-   - **Solutions:**
-     - Verify internet connectivity
-     - Check API key validity
-     - Configure proxy if needed
-     - Use `--timeout` to adjust connection timeout
- 
- - **Model Download Issues**
- 
-   - **Error:** `Model download failed`
-   - **Solutions:**
-     - Check available disk space
-     - Verify network stability
-     - Use `--resume` to continue interrupted downloads
-     - Try alternative download mirror
+ 1. **Slow Operations**
+    - Check resource limits
+    - Monitor memory usage
+    - Monitor CPU usage
+    - Check cache usage
+ 
+ 2. **High Resource Usage**
+    - Adjust memory limits
+    - Adjust CPU limits
+    - Optimize workflows
+    - Clear cache
+ 
+ ### Resource Issues
+ 
+ 1. **Memory Management**
+    - Monitor memory usage
+    - Set appropriate limits
+    - Clear unused resources
+    - Optimize operations
+ 
+ 2. **CPU Management**
+    - Monitor CPU usage
+    - Set appropriate limits
+    - Optimize operations
+    - Manage threads
  
  ### Plugin Issues
  
- - **Plugin Loading Failures**
- 
-   - **Error:** `Failed to load plugin`
-   - **Solutions:**
-     - Verify plugin compatibility
-     - Check plugin dependencies
-     - Reinstall plugin
-     - Check plugin logs
- 
- - **Plugin Conflicts**
- 
-   - **Error:** `Plugin conflict detected`
-   - **Solutions:**

+    - Check dependencies

  ## Our Pledge
  
- We as members, contributors, and leaders pledge to make participation in our community a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of age, body size, visible or invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity and expression, level of experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, or sexual identity and orientation.
- 
- We pledge to act and interact in ways that contribute to an open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, and healthy community.
- 
- > **See Also**: [Community Guidelines](../CONTRIBUTING.md#community-guidelines) for detailed guidelines.
+ As a solo developer, I pledge to:
+ 
+ - Maintain high ethical standards in development and usage
+ - Respect user privacy and data sovereignty
+ - Use resources responsibly and efficiently
+ - Document code and decisions thoroughly
+ - Keep security and safety as top priorities
+ - Follow best practices in AI development
+ - Maintain transparency in development process
+ - Ensure code quality and reliability
+ 
+ > **See Also**: [Development Guidelines](../CONTRIBUTING.md#development-guidelines) for detailed guidelines.
  
  ## Our Standards
  
- ### Examples of Behavior That Contributes to a Positive Environment
- 
- - Demonstrating empathy and kindness toward other people
- - Being respectful of differing opinions, viewpoints, and experiences
- - Giving and gracefully accepting constructive feedback
- - Accepting responsibility and apologizing to those affected by our mistakes
- - Focusing on what is best for the overall community
+ ### Examples of Ethical Development Practices
+ 
+ - Writing clear, maintainable, and well-documented code
+ - Implementing proper error handling and logging
+ - Following security best practices
+ - Managing resources efficiently
+ - Testing code thoroughly
+ - Documenting decisions and changes
+ - Maintaining data privacy
+ - Using AI responsibly
  
- ### Examples of Unacceptable Behavior
- 
- - The use of sexualized language or imagery and unwelcome sexual attention or advances
- - Trolling, insulting or derogatory comments, and personal or political attacks
- - Public or private harassment
- - Publishing others' private information without explicit permission
- - Other conduct which could reasonably be considered inappropriate in a professional setting
- 
- > **See Also**: [Community Standards](../CONTRIBUTING.md#community-standards) for detailed standards.
+ ### Examples of Unacceptable Practices
+ 
+ - Implementing insecure or unsafe code
+ - Mishandling user data or privacy
+ - Wasting system resources
+ - Using AI for harmful purposes
+ - Implementing biased or discriminatory code
+ - Ignoring security vulnerabilities
+ - Failing to document code
+ - Using unethical AI practices
+ 
+ > **See Also**: [Development Standards](../CONTRIBUTING.md#development-standards) for detailed standards.
  
  ## Scope
  
- This Code of Conduct applies within all community spaces, and also applies when an individual is officially representing the community in public spaces. Examples of representing our community include:
- 
- - Using an official e-mail address
- - Posting via an official social media account
- - Acting as an appointed representative at an online or offline event
- - Contributing to the project's documentation or codebase
+ This Code of Conduct applies to all aspects of the project, including:
+ 
+ - Code development and maintenance
+ - Documentation and guides
+ - Resource management
+ - Security practices
+ - Privacy handling
+ - AI implementation
+ - Testing and quality assurance
+ - Performance optimization
  
  > **See Also**: [Project Scope](../ARCHITECTURE.md#project-scope) for project boundaries.
  
- ## Reporting Guidelines
+ ## Ethical Guidelines
  
- ### How to Report
- 
- If you experience or witness unacceptable behavior, or have other concerns, please report it by contacting the project team at <conduct@nootropic.ai>. All reports will be handled with discretion.
- 
- In your report please include:
- 
- - Your contact information
- - Names of any individuals involved
- - When and where the incident occurred
- - Your account of what occurred
- - Any additional context
- - If you believe this incident is ongoing
- - If there are other relevant circumstances
- 
- > **See Also**: [Issue Reporting](../CONTRIBUTING.md#reporting-issues) for reporting guidelines.
- 
- ### What to Expect
- 
- After filing a report, a representative will contact you personally. The project team will then review the incident, follow up with any additional questions, and make a decision as to how to respond.
- 
- ## Enforcement
- 
- ### Consequences
- 
- Project maintainers who do not follow or enforce the Code of Conduct in good faith may face temporary or permanent repercussions as determined by other members of the project's leadership.
- 
- ### Enforcement Guidelines
- 
- 1. **Correction**
-    - Community Impact: Use of inappropriate language or other behavior deemed unprofessional or unwelcome
-    - Consequence: A private, written warning from project maintainers, providing clarity around the nature of the violation and an explanation of why the behavior was inappropriate
- 
- 2. **Warning**
-    - Community Impact: A violation through a single incident or series of actions
-    - Consequence: A warning with consequences for continued behavior
- 
- 3. **Temporary Ban**
-    - Community Impact: A serious violation of community standards
-    - Consequence: A temporary ban from any sort of interaction or public communication with the community
- 
- 4. **Permanent Ban**
-    - Community Impact: Demonstrating a pattern of violation of community standards
-    - Consequence: A permanent ban from any sort of public interaction within the community
- 
- > **See Also**: [Enforcement Process](../CONTRIBUTING.md#enforcement-process) for detailed procedures.
-

  ## Metrics Collection
  
- ### Collection Methods
- 
- - All metrics are collected locally by default using built-in instrumentation, logging, and monitoring tools.
- - Optional: Integrate with cloud or distributed monitoring systems if desired.
- - Metrics can be collected via CLI, API, or UI dashboards.
- 
- ### Data Sources
- 
- - Local application logs
- - Local system logs
- - Local model logs
- - Local storage (SQLite, JSON, or file-based)
- - Optional: Remote or cloud data sources (if enabled)

- 
- - Metrics are stored locally by default for privacy and data sovereignty.

- # Nx Metrics
- 
- ### Build Metrics
- 
- 1. **Build Performance Metrics**
-    ```yaml
-    # Prometheus metrics for builds
-    apiVersion: monitoring.coreos.com/v1
-    kind: ServiceMonitor
-    metadata:
-      name: nootropic-build-metrics
-    spec:
-      endpoints:
-      - port: metrics
-        path: /metrics
-        interval: 15s
-      selector:
-        matchLabels:
-          app: nootropic-build
-    ```
- 
- 2. **Build Analysis Metrics**
-    ```yaml
-    # Grafana dashboard for build analysis
-    apiVersion: v1
-    kind: ConfigMap
-    metadata:
-      name: nootropic-build-analysis
-    data:
-      dashboard.json: |
-        {
-          "panels": [
-            {
-              "title": "Build Duration",
-              "type": "graph",
-              "datasource": "Prometheus",
-              "targets": [
-                {
-                  "expr": "rate(nootropic_build_duration_seconds[5m])",
-                  "legendFormat": "Build Duration"
-                }
-              ]
-            },
-            {
-              "title": "Build Success Rate",
-              "type": "gauge",
-              "datasource": "Prometheus",
-              "targets": [
-                {
-                  "expr": "nootropic_build_success_rate",
-                  "legendFormat": "Success Rate"
-                }
-              ]
-            }
-          ]
-        }
-    ```
- 
- 3. **Build Alert Metrics**
-    ```yaml
-    # PrometheusRule for build metrics
-    apiVersion: monitoring.coreos.com/v1
-    kind: PrometheusRule
-    metadata:
-      name: nootropic-build-metrics
-    spec:
-      groups:
-      - name: nootropic.build
-        rules:
-        - alert: HighBuildDuration
-          expr: rate(nootropic_build_duration_seconds[5m]) > 300
-          for: 5m
-          labels:
-            severity: warning
-          annotations:
-            summary: High build duration
-            description: Build duration is above 5 minutes
-    ```
-

- ## Nx and pnpm Migration
- 
- ### Nx Migration
- 
- * **Nx Changes**
-   * Updated caching system
-   * Changed project graph
-   * New analytics (optional)
-   * New performance monitoring (optional)
-   * New dependency management
- 
- * **Migration Steps**
-   ```bash
-   # Update Nx
-   pnpm update nx@latest
- 
-   # Migrate cache (local)
-   pnpm nx cache migrate
- 
-   # Update project graph
-   pnpm nx graph --file=project-graph.json
-   ```
- 
- ### pnpm Migration
- 
- * **pnpm Changes**
-   * New workspace features
-   * Updated dependency resolution
-   * Changed lockfile format
-   * New store management
-   * New security features
-   * New performance optimizations
- 
- * **Migration Steps**
-   ```bash
-   # Update pnpm
-   pnpm add -g pnpm@latest
- 
-   # Update workspace
-   pnpm update
- 
-   # Migrate lockfile
-   pnpm install --fix-lockfile
- 
-   # Clean store
-   pnpm store prune
- 
-   # Verify dependencies
-   pnpm why
- 
-   # Check workspace
-   pnpm status
-   ```
- 
- ### Combined Migration Steps
- 
- 1. **Update Core Tools**
-    ```bash
-    # Update Nx and pnpm
-    pnpm add -g pnpm@latest
-    pnpm update nx@latest
- 
-    # Update workspace
-    pnpm update
-    ```
- 
- 2. **Migrate Configuration**
-    ```bash
-    # Update Nx config
-    pnpm nx migrate latest
- 
-    # Update pnpm config
-    pnpm config set store-dir .pnpm-store
-    pnpm config set cache-dir .pnpm-cache
-    ```
- 
- 3. **Migrate Dependencies**
-    ```bash
-    # Update dependencies
-    pnpm update
- 
-    # Fix lockfile
-    pnpm install --fix-lockfile
- 
-    # Clean store
-    pnpm store prune
-    ```
- 
- 4. **Migrate Cache**
-    ```bash
-    # Migrate Nx cache
-    pnpm nx cache migrate
- 
-    # Clean pnpm cache
-    pnpm store prune
-    ```
- 
- 5. **Verify Migration**
-    ```bash
-    # Check Nx status
-    pnpm nx show workspace
- 
-    # Check pnpm status
-    pnpm status
- 
-    # Verify dependencies
-    pnpm why
- 
-    # Test build
-    pnpm nx build
-    ```
- 
- ### Troubleshooting Migration
- 
- 1. **Cache Issues**
-    ```bash
-    # Reset Nx cache
-    pnpm nx reset
- 
-    # Clean pnpm store
-    pnpm store prune
- 
-    # Verify cache
-    pnpm nx show-cache
-    ```
- 
- 2. **Dependency Issues**
-    ```bash
-    # Fix dependencies
-    pnpm install --fix-lockfile
- 
-    # Rebuild dependencies
-    pnpm rebuild
- 
-    # Check dependency tree
-    pnpm why
-    ```
- 
- 3. **Workspace Issues**
-    ```bash
-    # Clean workspace
-    pnpm clean
- 
-    # Update workspace
-    pnpm update
- 
-    # Check workspace
-    pnpm status
-    ```
- 
- 4. **Build Issues**
-    ```bash
-    # Fix build
-    pnpm nx build --fix
- 
-    # Show build errors
-    pnpm nx show-errors
- 
-    # Show build logs
-    pnpm nx show-builds
-    ```
- 
- > **See Also**: [Nx Guide](../NX_GUIDE.md) and [Toolchain](../TOOLCHAIN.md) for detailed information about Nx and pnpm features.

- ## Nx Cloud Monitoring
- 
- ### Build Monitoring
- 
- 1. **Build Metrics**
-    ```bash
-    # Monitor build status
-    nx cloud:monitor build
- 
-    # View build history
-    nx cloud:history build
- 
-    # View build metrics
-    nx cloud:metrics build
-    ```
- 
- 2. **Build Analysis**
-    ```bash
-    # Analyze build performance
-    nx build --profile
- 
-    # View build graph
-    nx graph
- 
-    # View affected projects
-    nx affected:graph
-    ```
- 
- 3. **Build Alerts**
-    ```yaml
-    # PrometheusRule for build alerts
-    apiVersion: monitoring.coreos.com/v1
-    kind: PrometheusRule
-    metadata:
-      name: nootropic-build-alerts
-    spec:
-      groups:
-      - name: nootropic.build
-        rules:
-        - alert: BuildFailed
-          expr: nootropic_build_failed > 0
-          for: 5m
-          labels:
-            severity: critical
-          annotations:
-            summary: Build failed
-            description: A build operation has failed
-    ```
- 
- ### Test Monitoring
- 
- 1. **Test Metrics**
-    ```bash
-    # Monitor test status
-    nx cloud:monitor test
- 
-    # View test history
-    nx cloud:history test
- 
-    # View test metrics
-    nx cloud:metrics test
-    ```
- 
- 2. **Test Analysis**
-    ```bash
-    # Analyze test performance
-    nx test --profile
- 
-    # View test coverage
-    nx test --coverage
- 
-    # View test results
-    nx test --verbose
-    ```
- 
- 3. **Test Alerts**
-    ```yaml
-    # PrometheusRule for test alerts
-    apiVersion: monitoring.coreos.com/v1
-    kind: PrometheusRule
-    metadata:
-      name: nootropic-test-alerts
-    spec:
-      groups:
-      - name: nootropic.test
-        rules:
-        - alert: TestFailed
-          expr: nootropic_test_failed > 0
-          for: 5m
-          labels:
-            severity: critical
-          annotations:
-            summary: Test failed
-            description: A test operation has failed
-    ```
