	2.	Automate project scaffolding via custom generators that enforce nootropic’s conventions (JSON/YAML schemas, project references, capability registry), thereby minimizing configuration drift and onboarding friction.
	3.	Enforce architectural boundaries (linting, dependency constraints) to ensure free‐first, local‐first principles are upheld, and plugins adhere to approved dependency patterns.
	4.	Extend Nx with custom executors to manage complex workflows (e.g., RAG indexing, nightly LoRA training, Keptn remediation) in a standardized, repeatable manner.
	5.	Leverage Nx Cloud (or self‐hosted remote cache) to distribute expensive tasks—builds, tests, benchmark scripts—across multiple machines, minimizing CI runtime for large vector indexes or model fine‐tuning.
	6.	Use Nx’s integrated documentation tooling to generate real‐time API and CLI reference docs from source code, keeping documentation continuously in sync.
	7.	Adopt Nx’s advanced workspace‐level code sharing (shared libraries, TypeScript project references, import path aliases) to maximize code reuse across agents, adapters, and UI components.

Applying these practices will ensure nootropic remains performant on local hardware, scalable in CI, and extensible via plugins—without compromising its open‐source, local‐first philosophy.

⸻

1. Incremental Builds & Testing

1.1 Cached, Distributed Task Orchestration
	•	Nx Task Graph & Affected Commands
Nx automatically generates a directed acyclic graph (DAG) of project dependencies. When you run commands like nx affected:build or nx affected:test, Nx only rebuilds/tests projects impacted by the latest changes, rather than rebuilding the entire monorepo  ￼ ￼.
	•	For nootropic, where large vector‐store indexes or LoRA training jobs can be expensive, the ability to skip unaffected projects in CI accelerates feedback loops dramatically.
	•	Example: If a developer updates only libs/agents/coder-agent, Nx will rebuild/test only that agent (and any direct dependents), skipping the rest.
	•	Nx Cloud / Remote Caching
Nx Cloud (the hosted remote cache) or a self‐hosted remote cache allows sharing of build and test outputs across CI agents or developer machines  ￼ ￼.
	•	For nootropic’s RAG indexing: once ChromaDB index generation (embedding pipelines) or a large LoRA fine‐tuning run completes and its outputs are cached, subsequent CI runs on other branches can pull from the cache without repeating expensive work.
	•	Configuration Snippet (nx.json):

{
  "tasksRunnerOptions": {
    "default": {
      "runner": "@nrwl/workspace/tasks-runners/default",
      "options": {
        "cacheableOperations": ["build", "test", "lint", "e2e", "benchmark"],
        "remoteCache": {
          // Nx Cloud or self‐hosted gateway configuration
          "enabled": true 
        }
      }
    }
  }
}


￼ ￼.

1.2 Integrated Testing with Vitest & Affected Tests
	•	Vitest for Fast Unit Tests
Nx’s built‐in Vitest generator scaffolds configuration optimized for monorepos, including workspace caching and coverage thresholds  ￼ ￼.
	•	Place unit tests for each library (e.g., libs/agents/critic-agent) alongside implementation code; Vitest leverages tsconfig paths for seamless imports.
	•	Enforce a minimum coverage (e.g., 80 %) across all libs/**/src via vitest.config.ts.
	•	Affected Integration/E2E Tests
	•	Use nx affected:test to run only integration or end‐to‐end tests impacted by recent changes. This is particularly useful when vector‐store containerization (e.g., Chroma) is involved, reducing the CI time needed to spin up ephemeral databases.
	•	Example Workflow Step (GitHub Actions):

- name: Run affected tests
  run: pnpm nx affected:test --base=origin/main --head=HEAD


	•	Parallelization & Flakiness Detection
	•	Nx’s parallel execution (--parallel) combined with smart splitting of E2E tests (particularly Playwright or Cypress) ensures maximal utilization of CI runner CPUs.
	•	Plugins like Nx Flaky Test Detector can automatically rerun flaky tests and report reproducibility, critical for nootropic’s self‐healing CI pipeline  ￼ ￼.

⸻

2. Automated Project Scaffolding & Generators

2.1 Custom Nx Generators for Nootropic Conventions
	•	Standardizing Project Layout
	•	Create custom Nx generators (using nx g workspace-generator create-agent) to scaffold new agents, adapters, or UI libraries with pre‐configured project.json, tsconfig, and stubbed Protobuf definitions.
	•	Enforce folder structure:

libs/
  agents/
    <agent-name>/
      src/
        lib/
        index.ts
      project.json
      tsconfig.lib.json
  adapters/
    <adapter-name>/
      src/
      project.json
      tsconfig.lib.json


￼ ￼.

	•	Automatic Capability Registry Entry
	•	As part of the generator, include a step to update or create the agent’s entry in libs/shared/schemas/capability-registry.schema.json and regenerate describe-registry.json.
	•	Example generator snippet (TypeScript pseudo‐code):

import { Tree, formatFiles, generateFiles } from '@nrwl/devkit';

export default async function (tree: Tree, schema: { name: string }) {
  const libDir = `libs/agents/${schema.name}`;
  generateFiles(tree, path.join(__dirname, 'templates/agent'), libDir, { tmpl: '' });
  // Update capability-registry.json
  const registryPath = 'libs/shared/capability-registry.json';
  const registry = JSON.parse(tree.read(registryPath).toString());
  registry.capabilities[schema.name] = {
    name: schema.name,
    version: '0.1.0',
    description: '',
    dependencies: []
  };
  tree.write(registryPath, JSON.stringify(registry, null, 2));
  await formatFiles(tree);
}


￼ ￼.

	•	Scaffolding Example Projects
	•	Use Nx’s built‐in generators to quickly spin up the CLI, Electron, VS Code extension, and API:

nx g @nrwl/js:application cli --framework none --bundler esbuild
nx g @nrwl/node:application electron --bundler esbuild
nx g @nrwl/vscode:extension vscode-extension
nx g @nrwl/nest:application api


￼ ￼.

2.2 JSON/YAML Schemas & Zod Integration
	•	Schema‐Driven Configuration
	•	Keep shared schemas for project-spec.yaml, capability-registry.json, and model-metadata.json under libs/shared/src/schemas.
	•	Use Zod to generate both runtime validators and inform IDE auto‐completion.
	•	Nx generators can scaffold new schema files (e.g., zodSchema.ts) and update references in tsconfig.json paths to enable direct import of schemas from TypeScript code.
￼ ￼.

⸻

3. Enforcing Architectural Boundaries

3.1 Linting & Dependency Constraints
	•	ESLint with Nx Dependency Rules
	•	Leverage Nx’s eslintConfig and dependencyConstraints in nx.json to prevent circular or unintended dependencies. For example:

{
  "targetDependencies": {
    "build": [ /* ... */ ]
  },
  "namedInputs": { /* ... */ },
  "implicitDependencies": { /* ... */ },
  "projects": {
    "agents/*": { "tags": ["type:agent"] },
    "adapters/*": { "tags": ["type:adapter"] },
    "ui/*": { "tags": ["type:ui"] }
  },
  "linting": {
    "rules": [
      {
        "sourceTag": "type:adapter",
        "onlyDependOnLibsWithTags": ["type:shared", "type:library"]
      }
    ]
  }
}


￼ ￼.
	•	This ensures that, for instance, agents/* can only depend on shared/* and adapters/* but not directly on ui/*.

	•	Enforcing Free‐First, Local‐First
	•	Add custom lint rules or a Nx plugin that flags any direct import of paid/cloud‐only dependencies (e.g., openai SDK) within agent code unless behind a ModelAdapter abstraction.
	•	Example: In .eslintrc.json,

{
  "rules": {
    "no-restricted-imports": [
      "error",
      {
        "paths": [
          {
            "name": "openai",
            "message": "Import cloud LLMs only via ModelAdapter abstraction."
          }
        ]
      }
    ]
  }
}


￼ ￼.

3.2 TypeScript Project References & Path Aliases
	•	Strict TypeScript References
	•	Each library’s tsconfig.lib.json should declare "composite": true and reference dependent libraries. This ensures that nx build <lib> automatically triggers builds of its dependencies.
	•	Example (libs/adapters/model-adapter/tsconfig.lib.json):

{
  "extends": "../../tsconfig.base.json",
  "compilerOptions": {
    "composite": true,
    "declaration": true,
    "outDir": "../../dist/libs/adapters/model-adapter",
    "module": "ESNext",
    "moduleResolution": "NodeNext",
    "target": "ES2022"
  },
  "references": [
    { "path": "../shared" },
    { "path": "../runtime" }
  ],
  "include": ["src"]
}


￼ ￼.

	•	Path Alias Configuration
	•	In tsconfig.base.json, define:

{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "baseUrl": ".",
    "paths": {
      "@nootropic/shared/*": ["libs/shared/src/*"],
      "@nootropic/agents/*": ["libs/agents/*/src"],
      "@nootropic/adapters/*": ["libs/adapters/*/src"]
    }
  }
}


￼ ￼.
	•	This allows easy imports like import { TaskGraph } from '@nootropic/shared/models';.

4. Custom Executors & Complex Workflows

4.1 Building RAG Index Executor
	•	Nx Custom Executor
	•	Create a custom executor (libs/devtools/executors/generate-rag-index) that encapsulates:
	1.	Starting a local ChromaDB container (via Docker Compose).
	2.	Running chunking/embedding scripts (tools/rag/index.ts) that read repository files, chunk them, embed via ModelAdapter, and upsert into Chroma.
	3.	Export the index snapshot to LanceDB or MinIO for persistent storage.
	•	Executor Configuration (workspace.json):

"generate-rag-index": {
  "root": "libs/devtools",
  "executor": "nx:run-commands",
  "options": {
    "commands": [
      "docker-compose -f docker-compose.rag.yml up -d chromadb",
      "ts-node tools/rag/index.ts --output=./.vectorstore",
      "docker-compose -f docker-compose.rag.yml down"
    ],
    "cwd": "libs/devtools",
    "parallel": false
  }
}


￼ ￼.

	•	Scheduled RAG Indexing
	•	Use Nx’s support for scheduled targets via GitHub Actions or a self‐hosted cron runner to trigger nx run devtools:generate-rag-index nightly.
￼ ￼.

4.2 LoRA Fine‐tuning & Benchmark Executor
	•	LoRA Training Executor
	•	Define an executor (libs/devtools/executors/run-lora) that:
	1.	Reads a list of accepted (prompt,response) episodes from MemoryAgent.
	2.	Converts them into LoRA training data format.
	3.	Invokes Tabby ML or vLLM CLI to start fine‐tuning.
	4.	Outputs a new quantized model to models/ and uploads metrics to Prometheus.
	•	Executor Snippet:

"run-lora": {
  "root": "libs/devtools",
  "executor": "nx:run-commands",
  "options": {
    "commands": [
      "ts-node tools/lora/prepare.ts --episodes=./.nootropic-cache/episodes.json --output=./training/data.jsonl",
      "tabby-cli train --data ./training/data.jsonl --model starcoder2-q4 --output ./models/starcoder2-lora",
      "node tools/lora/report-metrics.js --model ./models/starcoder2-lora"
    ],
    "cwd": "libs/devtools",
    "parallel": false
  }
}

7. Advanced Code Sharing & Library Best Practices

7.1 Tagging & Scoped Libraries
	•	Project Tags in nx.json
	•	Assign tags like "type:agent", "type:adapter", "type:ui" to each project.json. Nx’s linting rules can then prevent improper dependencies (e.g., UI cannot depend directly on adapters).

	•	Use @nrwl/storybook:configuration to generate Storybook for libs/ui and any plugin UI.

8. Self‐Hosted Nx Cloud & Security Considerations

8.1 Self‐Hosted Remote Cache
	•	Nx Cloud vs. Self‐Hosted
	•	For a fully open‐source, on‐prem policy, host your own remote cache (e.g., via AWS S3 or MinIO) rather than using Nx’s cloud service.
	•	Setup:
	1.	Configure nx.json with:

"tasksRunnerOptions": {
  "default": {
    "runner": "@nrwl/workspace/tasks-runners/default",
    "options": {
      "remoteCache": {
        "url": "https://<self-hosted-cache-endpoint>",
        "accessKey": "<ACCESS_KEY>",
        "secretKey": "<SECRET_KEY>"
      }
    }
  }
}


	2.	Deploy a simple S3‐compatible service (MinIO) on Kubernetes with Helm.
￼ ￼.

	•	Securing the Cache
	•	Use TLS (Let’s Encrypt) for the cache endpoint.
	•	Configure IAM‐style policies (if using MinIO) to restrict read/write to CI service accounts only.

8.2 NX & Sensitive Data
	•	Dotenv & Environment Configuration
	•	Use @nrwl/nx-dotenv or a custom executor to load .env.local in dev.
	•	In CI, store secrets (e.g., OPENAI_API_KEY, VAULT_TOKEN, MINIO_ACCESS_KEY) in GitHub Actions Secrets or Vault, and inject via environment variables.
	•	Prevent accidental commits of .env by .gitignore, and add a pre‐commit Husky hook to scan for secrets (e.g., using git-secrets).
￼ ￼.

⸻

9. Example Nx‐Driven Workflow for Nootropic CI

name: CI

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]
  pull_request:
    branches: [main]

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v3

      - name: Setup Node.js
        uses: actions/setup-node@v3
        with:
          node-version: 18
          cache: "pnpm"
      
      - name: Install Dependencies
        run: pnpm install --frozen-lockfile

      - name: Restore Nx Cache
        uses: nx-cloud/cache-action@v2

      - name: Run Affected Build
        run: pnpm nx affected:build --base=origin/main --head=HEAD

      - name: Run Lint
        run: pnpm nx affected:lint --base=origin/main --head=HEAD

      - name: Run Affected Unit Tests
        run: pnpm nx affected:test --base=origin/main --head=HEAD

      - name: Start Chroma & Vector Index
        run: pnpm nx run devtools:generate-rag-index
        if: ${{ always() }}

      - name: Run Affected E2E
        run: pnpm nx affected:e2e --base=origin/main --head=HEAD

      - name: Save Nx Cache
        uses: nx-cloud/cache-action@v2

      - name: Upload Coverage
        uses: codecov/codecov-action@v3
        with:
          token: ${{ secrets.CODECOV_TOKEN }}
          files: ./coverage/lcov.info

￼ ￼ ￼.

10. Conclusion

By leveraging Nx’s advanced capabilities—incremental builds, distributed caching, custom generators and executors, workspace boundary enforcement, integrated documentation, and CI orchestration—we can make nootropic:
	•	Highly Performant and Scalable: Even large RAG indexes and model fine‐tuning jobs become tractable in CI and local dev.
	•	Consistently Configured: Custom generators guarantee every new agent or adapter conforms to nootropic’s architecture, preventing drift.
	•	Extensible Yet Governed: Nx’s dependency constraints and custom lint rules ensure third‐party plugins respect the free‐first, local‐first ethos.
	•	Future‐Proof: As Nx evolves (e.g., improved Rust‐powered task runner, new plugin ecosystem), nootropic can adopt best practices with minimal migration effort.

In summary, deep integration with Nx—while adhering to open‐source, local‐first principles—will allow nootropic to remain lean, dynamic, and developer‐friendly, fully realizing its vision of a self‐healing, AI‐driven development environment.

5. Best Practices

5.1 Nx Best Practices for a Local-First Approach
	•	Local caches over Nx Cloud by default:
	•	Document in NX_CACHING.md: how to run a local Nx cache (e.g., pnpm nx start --cloud=false) so no data ever leaves the machine.
	•	Explain trade-offs: local cache is faster in small teams but doesn’t share build artifacts across CI. Nx Cloud speeds up multi-dev or CI runs but sends hash metadata off-prem (though code never leaves).
	•	Strict Dependency Constraints:
	•	Use nx enforce-module-boundaries to prevent cross-team leaks (e.g., no agent should import directly from Electron UI).
	•	In nx.json, define tags like “type:agent,” “type:adapter,” “type:ui,” and add a lint rule so that no code in libs/adapters/* can depend on code in libs/ui/*.
	•	Prefer Implicit Dependencies Over Manual Steps:
	•	Whenever a library (e.g., model-adapter) relies on another (shared), encode that in tsconfig.lib.json references. This ensures nx run model-adapter:build --with-deps always builds shared first.
	•	Avoid adding “dummy” workspace dependencies just to force pnpm linking.

5.2 Documenting Nx Cloud vs. Self-Hosted Caching Trade-offs
	•	Section in NX_CACHING.md should cover:
	1.	Self-Hosted Cache
	•	How to start: pnpm nx daemon for local caching (no network).
	•	Pro: 100 % offline, no data in cloud; Con: only speeds up your machine, not CI.
	2.	Nx Cloud
	•	Setup: install @nrwl/nx-cloud, set environment variable NX_CLOUD=true, and commit the workspace config snippet.
	•	Pro: Shared cache across the team and CI, huge build speedups; Con: metadata about your tasks (hashes, command names) is stored off-prem—though code and secrets remain local.
	3.	When to use which
	•	Early prototype or fully air-gapped environments: always self-hosted.
	•	Larger team (3+ devs) or heavy CI needs: consider Nx Cloud, but document an acceptable privacy policy for the metadata stored.

+ # Nx Caching Guide
+ 
+ ## Overview
+ 
+ This guide explains how to configure and optimize Nx caching in nootropic, with a focus on local-first development and data sovereignty.
+ 
+ ## Table of Contents
+ 
+ 1. [Caching Strategies](#caching-strategies)
+ 2. [Local Caching](#local-caching)
+ 3. [Self-Hosted Caching](#self-hosted-caching)
+ 4. [Nx Cloud Integration](#nx-cloud-integration)
+ 5. [Cache Configuration](#cache-configuration)
+ 6. [Best Practices](#best-practices)
+ 
+ ## Caching Strategies
+ 
+ Nootropic supports three caching strategies:
+ 
+ 1. **Local Caching** (Default)
+    - Cache stored on local machine
+    - No network access required
+    - Fastest for single developer
+    - No sharing between machines
+ 
+ 2. **Self-Hosted Caching**
+    - Cache stored on internal server
+    - Shared across team
+    - Full control over data
+    - Requires infrastructure
+ 
+ 3. **Nx Cloud** (Optional)
+    - Managed cache service
+    - Shared across team and CI
+    - Metadata stored off-premises
+    - Requires internet access
+ 
+ ## Local Caching
+ 
+ ### Configuration
+ 
+ ```json
+ {
+   "tasksRunnerOptions": {
+     "default": {
+       "runner": "@nx/workspace/tasks-runners/default",
+       "options": {
+         "cacheableOperations": [
+           "build", "test", "lint", "e2e",
+           "benchmark", "generate-rag-index",
+           "run-lora", "generate-docs"
+         ],
+         "cacheDirectory": ".nx-cache"
+       }
+     }
+   }
+ }
+ ```
+ 
+ ### Usage
+ 
+ ```bash
+ # Start local cache daemon
+ nx daemon
+ 
+ # Clear local cache
+ nx reset
+ 
+ # View cache status
+ nx show projects
+ ```
+ 
+ ## Self-Hosted Caching
+ 
+ ### Setup
+ 
+ 1. Deploy MinIO server:
+ ```bash
+ # Using Docker
+ docker run -p 9000:9000 -p 9001:9001 \
+   -e "MINIO_ROOT_USER=admin" \
+   -e "MINIO_ROOT_PASSWORD=password" \
+   minio/minio server /data --console-address ":9001"
+ ```
+ 
+ 2. Configure nx.json:
+ ```json
+ {
+   "tasksRunnerOptions": {
+     "default": {
+       "runner": "@nx/workspace/tasks-runners/default",
+       "options": {
+         "remoteCache": {
+           "enabled": true,
+           "url": "http://localhost:9000",
+           "accessKey": "admin",
+           "secretKey": "password"
+         }
+       }
+     }
+   }
+ }
+ ```
+ 
+ ### Security
+ 
+ - Use TLS for cache endpoint
+ - Configure IAM policies
+ - Rotate access keys
+ - Monitor access logs
+ 
+ ## Nx Cloud Integration
+ 
+ ### Setup
+ 
+ 1. Install Nx Cloud:
+ ```bash
+ pnpm add -D @nrwl/nx-cloud
+ ```
+ 
+ 2. Configure nx.json:
+ ```json
+ {
+   "tasksRunnerOptions": {
+     "default": {
+       "runner": "@nrwl/nx-cloud",
+       "options": {
+         "accessToken": "<NX_CLOUD_TOKEN>",
+         "canTrackAnalytics": false,
+         "showUsageWarnings": true
+       }
+     }
+   }
+ }
+ ```
+ 
+ ### Privacy Considerations
+ 
+ - Only task metadata is stored
+ - No source code or secrets
+ - Can disable analytics
+ - Data retention policies
+ 
+ ## Cache Configuration
+ 
+ ### Cacheable Operations
+ 
+ ```json
+ {
+   "cacheableOperations": [
+     "build",
+     "test",
+     "lint",
+     "e2e",
+     "benchmark",
+     "generate-rag-index",
+     "run-lora",
+     "generate-docs"
+   ]
+ }
+ ```
+ 
+ ### Cache Keys
+ 
+ ```json
+ {
+   "namedInputs": {
+     "default": [
+       "{projectRoot}/**/*",
+       "sharedGlobals"
+     ],
+     "production": [
+       "default",
+       "!{projectRoot}/**/?(*.)+(spec|test).[jt]s?(x)?(.snap)",
+       "!{projectRoot}/tsconfig.spec.json",
+       "!{projectRoot}/.eslintrc.json"
+     ]
+   }
+ }
+ ```
+ 
+ ## Best Practices
+ 
+ ### Local Development
+ 
+ 1. **Default to Local Cache**
+    - Start with local caching
+    - Only enable remote cache when needed
+    - Monitor cache performance
+ 
+ 2. **Cache Optimization**
+    - Use appropriate cache keys
+    - Minimize cache size
+    - Regular cache cleanup
+    - Monitor disk usage
+ 
+ 3. **Security**
+    - Use TLS for remote cache
+    - Rotate access keys
+    - Monitor access logs
+    - Regular security audits
+ 
+ ### Team Development
+ 
+ 1. **Self-Hosted Cache**
+    - Deploy on internal network
+    - Configure access controls
+    - Monitor performance
+    - Regular maintenance
+ 
+ 2. **Nx Cloud**
+    - Review privacy policy
+    - Configure data retention
+    - Monitor usage
+    - Regular cost review
+ 
+ ### CI/CD Integration
+ 
+ 1. **Cache Configuration**
+    - Use appropriate runner
+    - Configure cache keys
+    - Monitor cache hits
+    - Regular cleanup
+ 
+ 2. **Performance**
+    - Monitor build times
+    - Track cache efficiency
+    - Optimize cache keys
+    - Regular review
+ 
+ ## See Also
+ 
+ - [Nx Guide](./NX_GUIDE.md): General Nx documentation
+ - [CI/CD Guide](./CI_CD.md): Using caching in CI/CD
+ - [Development Setup](./DEVELOPMENT_SETUP.md): Getting started with caching 
```

+ # Nx Generators Guide
+ 
+ ## Overview
+ 
+ This guide explains how to use and create custom generators in nootropic, focusing on local-first development and code generation best practices.
+ 
+ ## Table of Contents
+ 
+ 1. [Available Generators](#available-generators)
+ 2. [Using Generators](#using-generators)
+ 3. [Creating Generators](#creating-generators)
+ 4. [Generator Best Practices](#generator-best-practices)
+ 5. [Generator Examples](#generator-examples)
+ 
+ ## Available Generators
+ 
+ ### Project Generators
+ 
+ ```bash
+ # Generate a new application
+ nx g @nx/react:app my-app
+ 
+ # Generate a new library
+ nx g @nx/js:lib my-lib
+ 
+ # Generate a new tool
+ nx g @nx/js:lib my-tool --directory=tools
+ ```
+ 
+ ### Component Generators
+ 
+ ```bash
+ # Generate a React component
+ nx g @nx/react:component my-component --project=my-app
+ 
+ # Generate a library component
+ nx g @nx/react:component my-component --project=my-lib --export
+ ```
+ 
+ ### Custom Generators
+ 
+ ```bash
+ # Generate an agent
+ nx g @nootropic/agents:agent my-agent
+ 
+ # Generate an adapter
+ nx g @nootropic/adapters:adapter my-adapter
+ 
+ # Generate a UI component
+ nx g @nootropic/ui:component my-component
+ ```
+ 
+ ## Using Generators
+ 
+ ### Basic Usage
+ 
+ ```bash
+ # Generate with defaults
+ nx g @nx/react:app my-app
+ 
+ # Generate with options
+ nx g @nx/react:app my-app --directory=apps/my-app --tags=scope:my-app,type:app
+ ```
+ 
+ ### Generator Options
+ 
+ Common options for all generators:
+ 
+ - `--directory`: Target directory
+ - `--tags`: Project tags
+ - `--dry-run`: Show changes without applying
+ - `--verbose`: Show detailed output
+ 
+ ### Project Structure
+ 
+ Generated projects follow this structure:
+ 
+ ```
+ apps/
+   my-app/
+     src/
+       app/
+       assets/
+       styles/
+     project.json
+     tsconfig.json
+     ...
+ 
+ libs/
+   my-lib/
+     src/
+       lib/
+       index.ts
+     project.json
+     tsconfig.json
+     ...
+ ```
+ 
+ ## Creating Generators
+ 
+ ### Generator Structure
+ 
+ ```
+ tools/
+   generators/
+     my-generator/
+       schema.json
+       generator.ts
+       files/
+         __name__/
+           __name__.ts.template
+           __name__.spec.ts.template
+ ```
+ 
+ ### Schema Definition
+ 
+ ```json
+ {
+   "$schema": "http://json-schema.org/schema",
+   "cli": "nx",
+   "id": "my-generator",
+   "type": "object",
+   "properties": {
+     "name": {
+       "type": "string",
+       "description": "Name of the generated item",
+       "$default": {
+         "$source": "argv",
+         "index": 0
+       }
+     },
+     "directory": {
+       "type": "string",
+       "description": "Directory where the item is placed"
+     },
+     "tags": {
+       "type": "string",
+       "description": "Tags to add to the project"
+     }
+   },
+   "required": ["name"]
+ }
+ ```
+ 
+ ### Generator Implementation
+ 
+ ```typescript
+ import {
+   Tree,
+   formatFiles,
+   generateFiles,
+   joinPathFragments,
+   names
+ } from '@nx/devkit';
+ 
+ interface Schema {
+   name: string;
+   directory?: string;
+   tags?: string;
+ }
+ 
+ export default async function (tree: Tree, schema: Schema) {
+   const options = {
+     ...schema,
+     ...names(schema.name)
+   };
+ 
+   generateFiles(
+     tree,
+     joinPathFragments(__dirname, 'files'),
+     options.directory || '.',
+     options
+   );
+ 
+   await formatFiles(tree);
+ }
+ ```
+ 
+ ## Generator Best Practices
+ 
+ ### Code Generation
+ 
+ 1. **Templates**
+    - Use clear template syntax
+    - Include helpful comments
+    - Follow project conventions
+    - Include tests
+ 
+ 2. **Configuration**
+    - Use schema validation
+    - Provide sensible defaults
+    - Document all options
+    - Include examples
+ 
+ 3. **Testing**
+    - Test generator output
+    - Verify file structure
+    - Check content generation
+    - Validate options
+ 
+ ### Project Organization
+ 
+ 1. **Directory Structure**
+    - Follow Nx conventions
+    - Use clear naming
+    - Maintain consistency
+    - Document structure
+ 
+ 2. **File Organization**
+    - Group related files
+    - Use clear naming
+    - Follow patterns
+    - Document purpose
+ 
+ ## Generator Examples
+ 
+ ### Agent Generator
+ 
+ ```typescript
+ // tools/generators/agent/schema.json
+ {
+   "$schema": "http://json-schema.org/schema",
+   "cli": "nx",
+   "id": "agent",
+   "type": "object",
+   "properties": {
+     "name": {
+       "type": "string",
+       "description": "Agent name",
+       "$default": {
+         "$source": "argv",
+         "index": 0
+       }
+     },
+     "type": {
+       "type": "string",
+       "enum": ["task", "assistant", "specialist"],
+       "description": "Agent type"
+     }
+   },
+   "required": ["name", "type"]
+ }
+ ```
+ 
+ ### Adapter Generator
+ 
+ ```typescript
+ // tools/generators/adapter/schema.json
+ {
+   "$schema": "http://json-schema.org/schema",
+   "cli": "nx",
+   "id": "adapter",
+   "type": "object",
+   "properties": {
+     "name": {
+       "type": "string",
+       "description": "Adapter name",
+       "$default": {
+         "$source": "argv",
+         "index": 0
+       }
+     },
+     "model": {
+       "type": "string",
+       "description": "Target model"
+     }
+   },
+   "required": ["name", "model"]
+ }
+ ```
+ 
+ ### UI Component Generator
+ 
+ ```typescript
+ // tools/generators/ui-component/schema.json
+ {
+   "$schema": "http://json-schema.org/schema",
+   "cli": "nx",
+   "id": "ui-component",
+   "type": "object",
+   "properties": {
+     "name": {
+       "type": "string",
+       "description": "Component name",
+       "$default": {
+         "$source": "argv",
+         "index": 0
+       }
+     },
+     "type": {
+       "type": "string",
+       "enum": ["atom", "molecule", "organism"],
+       "description": "Component type"
+     }
+   },
+   "required": ["name", "type"]
+ }
+ ```
+ 
+ ## See Also
+ 
+ - [Nx Guide](./NX_GUIDE.md): General Nx documentation
+ - [Project Structure](./PROJECT_STRUCTURE.md): Understanding generated projects
+ - [Development Setup](./DEVELOPMENT_SETUP.md): Setting up for development 
```

+ # Nx Executors Guide
+ 
+ ## Overview
+ 
+ This guide explains how to use and create custom executors in nootropic, focusing on local-first development and task execution best practices.
+ 
+ ## Table of Contents
+ 
+ 1. [Available Executors](#available-executors)
+ 2. [Using Executors](#using-executors)
+ 3. [Creating Executors](#creating-executors)
+ 4. [Executor Best Practices](#executor-best-practices)
+ 5. [Executor Examples](#executor-examples)
+ 
+ ## Available Executors
+ 
+ ### Build Executors
+ 
+ ```json
+ {
+   "targets": {
+     "build": {
+       "executor": "@nx/vite:build",
+       "outputs": ["{options.outputPath}"],
+       "options": {
+         "outputPath": "dist/apps/my-app"
+       }
+     }
+   }
+ }
+ ```
+ 
+ ### Test Executors
+ 
+ ```json
+ {
+   "targets": {
+     "test": {
+       "executor": "@nx/jest:jest",
+       "outputs": ["{workspaceRoot}/coverage/{projectRoot}"],
+       "options": {
+         "jestConfig": "apps/my-app/jest.config.ts"
+       }
+     }
+   }
+ }
+ ```
+ 
+ ### Custom Executors
+ 
+ ```json
+ {
+   "targets": {
+     "generate-rag-index": {
+       "executor": "@nootropic/rag:generate-index",
+       "options": {
+         "inputPath": "data/docs",
+         "outputPath": "data/index"
+       }
+     },
+     "run-lora": {
+       "executor": "@nootropic/lora:train",
+       "options": {
+         "modelPath": "models/base",
+         "outputPath": "models/lora"
+       }
+     }
+   }
+ }
+ ```
+ 
+ ## Using Executors
+ 
+ ### Basic Usage
+ 
+ ```bash
+ # Run build executor
+ nx build my-app
+ 
+ # Run test executor
+ nx test my-app
+ 
+ # Run custom executor
+ nx generate-rag-index my-app
+ ```
+ 
+ ### Executor Options
+ 
+ Common options for all executors:
+ 
+ - `--watch`: Watch for changes
+ - `--verbose`: Show detailed output
+ - `--skip-nx-cache`: Skip cache
+ - `--parallel`: Run in parallel
+ 
+ ### Project Configuration
+ 
+ ```json
+ {
+   "targets": {
+     "build": {
+       "executor": "@nx/vite:build",
+       "outputs": ["{options.outputPath}"],
+       "options": {
+         "outputPath": "dist/apps/my-app",
+         "watch": false,
+         "verbose": false
+       },
+       "configurations": {
+         "production": {
+           "mode": "production"
+         },
+         "development": {
+           "mode": "development"
+         }
+       }
+     }
+   }
+ }
+ ```
+ 
+ ## Creating Executors
+ 
+ ### Executor Structure
+ 
+ ```
+ tools/
+   executors/
+     my-executor/
+       schema.json
+       executor.ts
+       implementation.ts
+ ```
+ 
+ ### Schema Definition
+ 
+ ```json
+ {
+   "$schema": "http://json-schema.org/schema",
+   "cli": "nx",
+   "id": "my-executor",
+   "type": "object",
+   "properties": {
+     "inputPath": {
+       "type": "string",
+       "description": "Input path"
+     },
+     "outputPath": {
+       "type": "string",
+       "description": "Output path"
+     },
+     "watch": {
+       "type": "boolean",
+       "description": "Watch for changes",
+       "default": false
+     }
+   },
+   "required": ["inputPath", "outputPath"]
+ }
+ ```
+ 
+ ### Executor Implementation
+ 
+ ```typescript
+ import {
+   ExecutorContext,
+   joinPathFragments,
+   logger
+ } from '@nx/devkit';
+ 
+ interface Schema {
+   inputPath: string;
+   outputPath: string;
+   watch?: boolean;
+ }
+ 
+ export default async function (
+   options: Schema,
+   context: ExecutorContext
+ ): Promise<{ success: boolean }> {
+   const { inputPath, outputPath, watch } = options;
+   const { workspaceRoot } = context;
+ 
+   try {
+     // Implementation logic here
+     logger.info(`Processing ${inputPath} to ${outputPath}`);
+     
+     if (watch) {
+       // Watch mode implementation
+     }
+ 
+     return { success: true };
+   } catch (error) {
+     logger.error(`Error: ${error.message}`);
+     return { success: false };
+   }
+ }
+ ```
+ 
+ ## Executor Best Practices
+ 
+ ### Task Execution
+ 
+ 1. **Error Handling**
+    - Use try-catch blocks
+    - Log errors clearly
+    - Return success status
+    - Handle edge cases
+ 
+ 2. **Performance**
+    - Use incremental builds
+    - Implement caching
+    - Optimize I/O
+    - Monitor resources
+ 
+ 3. **Configuration**
+    - Validate options
+    - Use sensible defaults
+    - Document options
+    - Include examples
+ 
+ ### Project Organization
+ 
+ 1. **Directory Structure**
+    - Follow Nx conventions
+    - Use clear naming
+    - Maintain consistency
+    - Document structure
+ 
+ 2. **File Organization**
+    - Group related files
+    - Use clear naming
+    - Follow patterns
+    - Document purpose
+ 
+ ## Executor Examples
+ 
+ ### RAG Index Generator
+ 
+ ```typescript
+ // tools/executors/rag-generate-index/schema.json
+ {
+   "$schema": "http://json-schema.org/schema",
+   "cli": "nx",
+   "id": "rag-generate-index",
+   "type": "object",
+   "properties": {
+     "inputPath": {
+       "type": "string",
+       "description": "Path to input documents"
+     },
+     "outputPath": {
+       "type": "string",
+       "description": "Path to output index"
+     },
+     "chunkSize": {
+       "type": "number",
+       "description": "Chunk size for indexing",
+       "default": 1000
+     }
+   },
+   "required": ["inputPath", "outputPath"]
+ }
+ ```
+ 
+ ### LoRA Trainer
+ 
+ ```typescript
+ // tools/executors/lora-train/schema.json
+ {
+   "$schema": "http://json-schema.org/schema",
+   "cli": "nx",
+   "id": "lora-train",
+   "type": "object",
+   "properties": {
+     "modelPath": {
+       "type": "string",
+       "description": "Path to base model"
+     },
+     "outputPath": {
+       "type": "string",

+     }

+ 
+ ### Documentation Generator
+ 
+ ```typescript
+ // tools/executors/generate-docs/schema.json

+ # Nx Architecture Guide
+ 
+ ## Overview
+ 
+ This guide explains how to use Nx to enforce architectural boundaries and maintain a clean, modular codebase in nootropic, focusing on local-first development and code organization best practices.

+ ## Architectural Boundaries
+ 
+ ### Layer Boundaries
+ 
+ 1. **Application Layer**
+    - Desktop, Web, CLI apps
+    - User interface
+    - Application logic
+    - No direct model access
+ 
+ 2. **Domain Layer**
+    - Agents and adapters

+    - Model integration
+    - No UI dependencies
+ 
+ 3. **Core Layer**
+    - Shared functionality
+    - Data structures
+    - Utilities
+    - No external dependencies
+

+

+ }

+ ## Nx Testing Integration
+ 
+ ### Test Configuration
+ 
+ ```json
+ // nx.json
+ {
+   "targetDefaults": {
+     "test": {
+       "inputs": [
+         "default",
+         "^production",
+         "{workspaceRoot}/jest.config.ts"
+       ],
+       "dependsOn": ["^build"],
+       "cache": true
+     }
+   },
+   "plugins": [
+     {
+       "plugin": "@nx/jest/plugin",
+       "options": {
+         "testTarget": "test"
+       }
+     }
+   ]
+ }
+ ```
+ 
+ ### Test Execution
+ 
+ ```bash
+ # Run all tests
+ pnpm nx run-many --target=test --all
+ 
+ # Run tests for affected projects
+ pnpm nx affected:test
+ 
+ # Run tests for a specific project
+ pnpm nx test <project-name>
+ 
+ # Run tests in parallel
+ pnpm nx run-many --target=test --all --parallel=3
+ 
+ # Run tests with coverage
+ pnpm nx test <project-name> --coverage
+ ```
+ 
+ ### Test Caching
+ 
+ ```json
+ // project.json
+ {
+   "targets": {
+     "test": {
+       "executor": "@nx/jest:jest",
+       "outputs": ["{workspaceRoot}/coverage/{projectRoot}"],
+       "options": {
+         "jestConfig": "libs/my-lib/jest.config.ts",
+         "passWithNoTests": true,
+         "coverageReporters": ["text", "lcov"],
+         "coverageDirectory": "coverage"
+       },
+       "configurations": {
+         "ci": {
+           "ci": true,
+           "codeCoverage": true
+         }
+       }
+     }
+   }
+ }
  ```

+    ```yaml
+    nx:

+        metrics:
+          - name: project_count
+            type: gauge
+            labels: [type, status]
+          - name: dependency_count
+            type: gauge
+            labels: [type, status]
+          - name: configuration_validity
+            type: gauge
+            labels: [type, status]

+            type: gauge
+            labels: [component, status]
+        storage:
+          type: sqlite
+          path: .nootropic-cache/analytics/nx/workspace.db

+          days: 30
+        privacy:
+          anonymize: true
+          encryption: true
+    ```

+            type: gauge
+            labels: [type, status]

+            type: gauge
+            labels: [component, status]
+          - name: graph_performance
+            type: histogram
+            labels: [operation, status]

+          type: sqlite
+          path: .nootropic-cache/analytics/nx/graph.db

+          days: 30

     ```
  
+ ### 2. Project Configuration
+ 
+ 1. **Application Projects**
+    ```json
+    {
+      "name": "nootropic-cli",
+      "$schema": "../../node_modules/nx/schemas/project-schema.json",
+      "sourceRoot": "apps/cli/src",
+      "projectType": "application",
+      "targets": {
+        "build": {
+          "executor": "@nx/vite:build",
+          "outputs": ["{options.outputPath}"],
+          "defaultConfiguration": "production",
+          "options": {
+            "outputPath": "dist/apps/cli"
+          },
+          "configurations": {
+            "development": {
+              "mode": "development"
+            },
+            "production": {
+              "mode": "production"
+            }
+          }
+        },
+        "serve": {
+          "executor": "@nx/vite:dev-server",
+          "defaultConfiguration": "development",
+          "options": {
+            "buildTarget": "nootropic-cli:build"
+          },
+          "configurations": {
+            "development": {
+              "buildTarget": "nootropic-cli:build:development",
+              "hmr": true
+            },
+            "production": {
+              "buildTarget": "nootropic-cli:build:production",
+              "hmr": false
+            }
+          }
+        },
+        "test": {
+          "executor": "@nx/jest:jest",
+          "outputs": ["{workspaceRoot}/coverage/{projectRoot}"],
+          "options": {
+            "jestConfig": "apps/cli/jest.config.ts"
+          }
+        },
+        "lint": {
+          "executor": "@nx/eslint:lint",
+          "outputs": ["{options.outputFile}"]
+        }
+      },
+      "tags": ["scope:app", "type:feature"]
+    }
+    ```
+ 
+ 2. **Library Projects**
+    ```json
+    {
+      "name": "shared-utils",
+      "$schema": "../../node_modules/nx/schemas/project-schema.json",
+      "sourceRoot": "libs/shared/src",
+      "projectType": "library",
+      "targets": {
+        "build": {
+          "executor": "@nx/js:tsc",
+          "outputs": ["{options.outputPath}"],
+          "options": {
+            "outputPath": "dist/libs/shared",
+            "main": "libs/shared/src/index.ts",
+            "tsConfig": "libs/shared/tsconfig.lib.json",
+            "assets": ["libs/shared/*.md"]
+          }
+        },
+        "test": {
+          "executor": "@nx/jest:jest",
+          "outputs": ["{workspaceRoot}/coverage/{projectRoot}"],
+          "options": {
+            "jestConfig": "libs/shared/jest.config.ts"
+          }
+        },
+        "lint": {
+          "executor": "@nx/eslint:lint",
+          "outputs": ["{options.outputFile}"]
+        }
+      },
+      "tags": ["scope:lib", "type:util"]
+    }
+    ```
+ 
+ ### 3. Build Configuration
+ 
+ 1. **Vite Configuration**
+    ```typescript
+    // apps/cli/vite.config.ts
+    import { defineConfig } from 'vite';
+    import { resolve } from 'path';
+ 
+    export default defineConfig({
+      build: {
+        target: 'esnext',
+        outDir: 'dist/apps/cli',
+        rollupOptions: {
+          input: {
+            main: resolve(__dirname, 'src/main.ts'),
+          },
+          output: {
+            format: 'es',
+            entryFileNames: '[name].js',
+            chunkFileNames: '[name].js',
+            assetFileNames: '[name].[ext]',
+          },
+        },
+      },
+      optimizeDeps: {
+        exclude: ['@nootropic/core'],
+      },
+    });
+    ```
+ 
+ 2. **TypeScript Configuration**
+    ```json
+    // tsconfig.base.json
+    {
+      "compileOnSave": false,
+      "compilerOptions": {
+        "rootDir": ".",
+        "sourceMap": true,
+        "declaration": false,
+        "moduleResolution": "node",
+        "emitDecoratorMetadata": true,
+        "experimentalDecorators": true,
+        "importHelpers": true,
+        "target": "es2015",
+        "module": "esnext",
+        "lib": ["es2020", "dom"],
+        "skipLibCheck": true,
+        "skipDefaultLibCheck": true,
+        "baseUrl": ".",
+        "paths": {
+          "@nootropic/shared": ["libs/shared/src/index.ts"],
+          "@nootropic/core": ["libs/core/src/index.ts"],
+          "@nootropic/adapters": ["libs/adapters/src/index.ts"],
+          "@nootropic/ai": ["libs/ai/src/index.ts"]
+        }
+      },
+      "exclude": ["node_modules", "tmp"]
+    }
+    ```
+ 
+ ### 4. Test Configuration
+ 
+ 1. **Jest Configuration**
+    ```typescript
+    // jest.config.ts
+    import { getJestConfig } from '@nx/jest';
+ 
+    export default getJestConfig({
+      displayName: 'nootropic-cli',
+      preset: '../../jest.preset.js',
+      testEnvironment: 'node',
+      transform: {
+        '^.+\\.[tj]s$': ['ts-jest', { tsconfig: '<rootDir>/tsconfig.spec.json' }],
+      },
+      moduleFileExtensions: ['ts', 'js', 'html'],
+      coverageDirectory: '../../coverage/apps/cli',
+      testMatch: ['**/?(*.)+(spec|test).[jt]s?(x)'],
+    });
+    ```
+ 
+ 2. **E2E Configuration**
+    ```typescript
+    // apps/cli-e2e/cypress.config.ts
+    import { defineConfig } from 'cypress';
+    import { nxE2EPreset } from '@nx/cypress/plugins/cypress-preset';
+ 
+    export default defineConfig({
+      e2e: {
+        ...nxE2EPreset(__dirname),
+        baseUrl: 'http://localhost:4200',
+        supportFile: 'apps/cli-e2e/support/e2e.ts',
+        specPattern: 'apps/cli-e2e/e2e/**/*.cy.{js,jsx,ts,tsx}',
+      },
+    });
+    ```
+

+ ## Nx Commands Reference
+ 
+ ### Project Management
+ ```bash
+ # Create a new project
+ pnpm nx generate @nx/react:app my-app
+ pnpm nx generate @nx/js:lib my-lib
+ 
+ # List all projects
+ pnpm nx list
+ 
+ # Show project details
+ pnpm nx show project <project-name>
+ ```
+ 
+ ### Task Execution
+ ```bash
+ # Run a specific task
+ pnpm nx <target> <project>
+ 
+ # Run multiple tasks
+ pnpm nx run-many --target=<target> --projects=<project1>,<project2>
+ 
+ # Run affected tasks
+ pnpm nx affected:<target>
+ ```
+ 
+ ### Graph & Dependencies
+ ```bash
+ # View project graph
+ pnpm nx graph
+ 
+ # View dependency graph
+ pnpm nx dep-graph
+ 
+ # View affected projects
+ pnpm nx affected:graph
+ ```
+ 
+ ### Cache Management
+ ```bash
+ # Clear cache
+ pnpm nx reset
+ 
+ # Show cache status
+ pnpm nx show cache
+ 
+ # Show cache details
+ pnpm nx show cache --verbose
+ ```
+ 
+ ### Workspace Management
+ ```bash
+ # Update workspace
+ pnpm nx migrate latest
+ 
+ # Generate workspace documentation
+ pnpm nx graph --file=docs/graph.html
+ 
+ # Show workspace status
+ pnpm nx show workspace
+ ```
```

+ # SearchAgent

+ ## Summary
+ 
+ The **SearchAgent** is an intelligent agent responsible for orchestrating search operations and providing high-level search capabilities to other components in the system. It leverages the SearchAdapter to perform actual search operations while adding agent-specific logic, context management, and result processing.
+ 
+ Key functions include:
+ 
+ * Orchestrating search operations across different contexts
+ * Managing search context and history
+ * Processing and refining search results
+ * Implementing search strategies and heuristics
+ * Coordinating with other agents for complex search tasks
+ 
+ ***
+

+    * Handle complex search scenarios

+     
+     // 3. Execute search using adapter

+     // 4. Process and refine results

  ## Summary
  
- The **SearchAdapter** is responsible for providing a unified interface for retrieving relevant code snippets, documentation, and contextual information from project repositories and external knowledge sources using a hybrid Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) approach. It abstracts the underlying vector and keyword search implementations, allowing agents to seamlessly access both dense vector search (e.g., Chroma) and sparse keyword search (e.g., Weaviate or Elasticsearch) capabilities.
+ The **SearchAdapter** is a low-level component responsible for providing the core search functionality to the SearchAgent. It handles the actual search operations, storage abstraction, and result processing, while the SearchAgent provides higher-level orchestration and context management.
  
  Key functions include:
  
- * Providing a consistent interface for indexing and searching across different storage backends
- * Managing the lifecycle of vector and inverted-index stores
- * Handling query routing and result fusion
- * Implementing caching and fallback strategies
- * Ensuring proper resource management and cleanup

Explanation of Each Directory/Component
	•	apps/: Top‐level runnable applications.
	•	cli/: The nootropic command‐line tool (built with Commander.js + Nx Node executor).
	•	electron/: The desktop dashboard (Electron + React) for visualization, metrics, timelines, plugin manager.
	•	vscode/: The VS Code extension (Continue‐based) exposing slash commands and LSP for real‐time coding.
	•	api/: A NestJS (or Express) REST/gRPC server that the CLI/Electron could optionally invoke remotely.
	•	temporal/: Hosts Temporal workers and workflow definitions (e.g., for nightly LoRA fine‐tuning, CI self‐healing).
	•	libs/agents/: Each agent (Planner, Coder, Critic, Reasoning, Search, Feedback, ProjectMgr, Explainability, Memory, Observability) is a standalone Nx library with:
	•	Its own project.json defining build/test/serve targets.
	•	A src/ folder containing a service implementation (*.service.ts) and any Protobuf client‐stubs.
	•	libs/adapters/: Each adapter (ModelAdapter, StorageAdapter, ObservabilityAdapter, PluginLoaderAdapter, ReflexionAdapter, SearchAdapter) is an Nx library that:
	•	Wraps external systems (LLM runtimes, vector DBs, telemetry, plugin discovery, event buses).
	•	Can be consumed by multiple agents.
	•	libs/shared/: Common types, JSON schemas, Zod schemas, utility functions, and constants used across agents and adapters.
	•	Contains schemas/ (project‐spec, capability registry, agent‐state).
	•	Contains utils/ (logging helpers, environment constants).
	•	Contains types/ for shared interfaces.
	•	libs/ui/: Reusable React components (buttons, cards, timeline, plugin manager UI, explainability panel) and styling (Tailwind config) used by Electron and VS Code (via webviews).
	•	libs/runtime/: Core runtime files for error classes, a shared Pino/Winston logger setup, and common initialization logic.
	•	libs/context/: Context management for current project, user session, and environment variables—injectable via Dependency Injection or Context APIs.
	•	libs/tools/: Custom utility scripts and Nx generators:
	•	cache‐warm.ts: Preloads frequently used embeddings into Redis.
	•	benchmark/: Scripts to compare model inference (Llama 2 vs. StarCoder 2) and output CSV/JSON for reports.
	•	migrations/: Data transformation scripts for schema migrations (e.g., transforming old project specs).
	•	rotate‐keys.ts: Periodically rotate API keys stored in Vault.
	•	workspace.json: Globally declares every project under apps/, libs/, and tools/, as well as their targets (build, test, lint, serve, custom executors).
	•	nx.json: Configures Nx-specific settings:
	•	implicitDependencies so that building a downstream library (e.g., model-adapter) automatically builds its upstream (e.g., shared).
	•	tasksRunnerOptions for distributed caching and parallelism.
	•	Project tags and optional affected constraints (e.g., forbid api from importing electron).
	•	tsconfig.base.json: Contains root TypeScript compiler options (e.g.: "module": "ESNext", "moduleResolution": "NodeNext", path aliases so that @nootropic/shared maps to dist/libs/shared/*.js after build).
	•	pnpm-workspace.yaml: Ensures PNPM treats apps/, libs/, and tools/ as workspace packages, enabling the workspace:* protocol in inter-package dependencies.
	•	.env.local: Local environment variables for development, such as

CHROMA_HOST=http://localhost:8000  
TEMPORAL_HOST=localhost:7233  
REDIS_URL=redis://localhost:6379  
LOG_LEVEL=debug  


	•	project-spec.yaml: Example project specification that PlannerAgent will parse (matching the JSON Schema under libs/shared/schemas/project-spec.schema.json).
	•	package.json (root): May declare dev dependencies (e.g., Nx, TypeScript, ESLint, Tailwind, Prettier) and a dependency on @nootropic/cli for easy invocation ("cli": "workspace:apps/cli").

⸻

Key Points
	1.	Clear separation between “apps” and “libs”
	•	apps/ contains runnable entry points (CLI, Electron, VS Code, API, Temporal worker).
	•	libs/ contains reusable code (agents, adapters, UI components, shared utilities).
	2.	One Nx project per agent/adapter
	•	Each agent or adapter has its own project.json so it can be built or tested independently:

  },
  "tags": ["scope:agents"]
}


	3.	Implicit Dependencies
	•	In nx.json, we might set:

{
  "projects": {
    "model-adapter": { "implicitDependencies": ["shared", "runtime"] },
    "search-adapter": { "implicitDependencies": ["shared", "runtime"] },
    // … etc.
  }
}


	•	Ensures that if libs/shared changes, any library depending on it (e.g., model-adapter) is rebuilt.

	4.	Path Aliases & Project References
	•	In tsconfig.base.json, define:

{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "baseUrl": ".",
    "paths": {
      "@nootropic/shared/*": ["dist/libs/shared/*.js"],
      "@nootropic/runtime/*": ["dist/libs/runtime/*.js"],
      "@nootropic/ui/*": ["libs/ui/src/*"]
    }
  }
}


	•	Each library’s tsconfig.lib.json extends the base and includes "composite": true so that TypeScript project references track build order.

	5.	Tooling Integration under tools/
	•	Custom Nx generators or executors can live under libs/tools (e.g., a generator for new agent skeletons).
	•	Benchmark and migration scripts can be invoked via Nx commands:

nx run tools:benchmark
nx run tools:migrate



By following this Nx directory layout, we ensure:
	•	Modular code organization—each agent/adapter/UI component is independently buildable and testable.
	•	Scalable build pipeline—Nx’s distributed caching and affected commands speed up CI.
	•	Clear boundaries—implicit dependencies and project tags enforce architectural constraints (e.g., agents only import adapters, not other agents).
	•	Developer ergonomics—generators, linting, and path aliases make it effortless to add new features without broken imports or stale caches.

This complete Nx directory structure captures every single component (apps, libs, tools) needed to fully scaffold and build nootropic from end to end.

```diff
- 
+ import { Injectable } from '@nestjs/common';
+ import { Logger } from '@nootropic/runtime';
+ import { AgentError } from '@nootropic/runtime';
+ import { ModelAdapter } from '@nootropic/adapters/model-adapter';
+ import { StorageAdapter } from '@nootropic/adapters/storage-adapter';
+ import { ProjectContextService } from '@nootropic/context';
+ 
+ export interface CodeGenerationResult {
+   code: string;
+   explanation: string;
+   tests?: string;
+   metadata: {
+     language: string;
+     framework?: string;
+     dependencies?: string[];
+   };
+ }
+ 
+ @Injectable()
+ export class CoderService {
+   private readonly logger = new Logger(CoderService.name);
+ 
+   constructor(
+     private readonly modelAdapter: ModelAdapter,
+     private readonly storageAdapter: StorageAdapter,
+     private readonly projectContext: ProjectContextService
+   ) {}
+ 
+   async generateCode(params: {
+     description: string;
+     language: string;
+     framework?: string;
+     context?: string;
+   }): Promise<CodeGenerationResult> {
+     try {
+       this.logger.info('Generating code', { params });
+ 
+       // Get project context
+       const context = await this.projectContext.getContext();
+ 
+       // Generate code using model
+       const prompt = this.buildCodeGenerationPrompt({
+         ...params,
+         projectContext: context
+       });
+ 
+       const response = await this.modelAdapter.generateText(prompt, {
+         provider: 'ollama',
+         model: 'codellama',
+         temperature: 0.2
+       });
+ 
+       // Parse and validate generated code
+       const result = this.parseCodeGenerationResponse(response.text);
+ 
+       // Store generated code
+       await this.storageAdapter.storeDocument({
+         id: `code_${Date.now()}`,
+         content: result.code,
+         metadata: {
+           type: 'generated_code',
+           ...result.metadata
+         }
+       });
+ 
+       return result;
+     } catch (error) {
+       throw new AgentError('Failed to generate code', { cause: error });
+     }
+   }
+ 
+   private buildCodeGenerationPrompt(params: {
+     description: string;
+     language: string;
+     framework?: string;
+     context?: string;
+     projectContext: any;
+   }): string {
+     return `
+       Generate code for the following task:
+       
+       Description: ${params.description}
+       Language: ${params.language}
+       ${params.framework ? `Framework: ${params.framework}` : ''}
+       
+       ${params.context ? `Context:\n${params.context}` : ''}
+       
+       Project Context:
+       ${JSON.stringify(params.projectContext, null, 2)}
+       
+       Please provide:
+       1. The complete code implementation
+       2. A brief explanation of the implementation
+       3. Unit tests if applicable
+       4. Any required dependencies
+       
+       Format the response as:
+       CODE:
+       \`\`\`${params.language}
+       // Implementation here
+       \`\`\`
+       
+       EXPLANATION:
+       // Explanation here
+       
+       TESTS:
+       \`\`\`${params.language}
+       // Tests here
+       \`\`\`
+       
+       DEPENDENCIES:
+       // List of dependencies
+     `;
+   }
+ 
+   private parseCodeGenerationResponse(response: string): CodeGenerationResult {
+     try {
+       const codeMatch = response.match(/CODE:\s*```[\s\S]*?```/);
+       const explanationMatch = response.match(/EXPLANATION:\s*([\s\S]*?)(?=TESTS:|DEPENDENCIES:|$)/);
+       const testsMatch = response.match(/TESTS:\s*```[\s\S]*?```/);
+       const dependenciesMatch = response.match(/DEPENDENCIES:\s*([\s\S]*?)$/);
+ 
+       if (!codeMatch) {
+         throw new Error('No code found in response');
+       }
+ 
+       const code = codeMatch[0].replace(/CODE:\s*```\w*\n/, '').replace(/```$/, '');
+       const explanation = explanationMatch ? explanationMatch[1].trim() : '';
+       const tests = testsMatch ? testsMatch[0].replace(/TESTS:\s*```\w*\n/, '').replace(/```$/, '') : undefined;
+       const dependencies = dependenciesMatch ? dependenciesMatch[1].trim().split('\n') : [];
+ 
+       return {
+         code,
+         explanation,
+         tests,
+         metadata: {
+           language: 'typescript', // Default to TypeScript
+           dependencies
+         }
+       };
+     } catch (error) {
+       throw new AgentError('Failed to parse code generation response', { cause: error });
+     }
+   }
+ } 
```

   - `agents/` - Individual agent libraries (planner, coder, critic, etc.)
   - `adapters/` - Various adapters (model, storage, observability, etc.)
   - `shared/` - Shared schemas, types, and utilities
   - `ui/` - Shared React UI components
   - `runtime/` - Core runtime functionality
   - `context/` - Cross-cutting context management
   - `tools/` - Custom scripts and utilities

3. **Root Configuration Files**:
   - `workspace.json` - Project definitions
   - `nx.json` - Nx configuration
   - `tsconfig.base.json` - TypeScript configuration
   - `pnpm-workspace.yaml` - Workspace package definitions
   - `.env.local` - Environment variables
   - `project-spec.yaml` - Project specification
   - `package.json` - Root package configuration

The structure follows a modular architecture with clear separation of concerns between applications, libraries, and configuration. Each component (agent, adapter) is isolated in its own library, making the codebase maintainable and scalable.
